div1.p: The Man's bewitch'd; OR, The Devil to do about Her. A COMEDY, As it is Acted at the NEW-THEATRE IN THE HAY-MARKET; BY HER MAJESTY's SERVANTS.
LONDON, Printed for BERNARD LINTOTT, between the Two Temple-Gates in Fleet-street.

div1.head: To His GRACE WILLIAM Duke of Devonshire; Lord Steward of Her Majesty's Houshold, Lord in Eyre, North of Trent, Lord Lieutenant of the County of Derby; and One of Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council, &c.
div1.p:
THE Muses were ever ambitious of being distinguish'd, by shrouding themselves under the Patronage of the greatest Men in all Ages; not made so by Titles or Preferment; but such, whose innate Principles of Honour, truly supported those their Prince had crown'd them with. From hence sprung my Presumption of laying the following Scenes at Your Grace's Feet; since the World must allow, that all those Virtues, which compleat a perfect good, as well as great Man, are
center'd in the Duke of Devonshire; the loyalest Subject, the tenderest Husband, and the kindest Master, that ever Monarch, Wife, or Servant had; Briliant Graces, but such as do not shine in every Man of Quality. From such Patriots, what may not Britain hope? Nay, what might not She command, were all her Sons as fervent for her Interest, and discharg'd their respective Trusts with that Fidelity, and due Regard to the publick Good, as Your Grace has ever done in Yours: Then the hated Name of Faction wou'd be heard no more, and the scandalous Wounds of hot-headed Parties heal'd; which is the only way to secure this Island from foreign Insults, and establish Peace more firmly, than Armies, tho' vast as Xerxes led, can do.

To attempt your Grace's Character, is the superiour business of a Masculine Pen, and not to be reach'd by mine: But since my Husband has the Honour to serve Her Majesty, under the Command of Your Grace, as he did the late King of glorious Memory, under that of your noble Father, I cou'd not be prevail'd upon to alter my
Resolution of prefixing your Grace's Name in the front of this Poem, at once to shew my Gratitude, and my Ambition: And if, when Your Grace's Mind's unbended from the Care and Business of the State, it finds the way in some leisure Hour to divert Your Grace, and the Author meet your Pardon for this Liberty, my Wishes are all answer'd; as I hope my Prayers will be, that Your Grace may enjoy a perfect Health, free from Pain in Mind, and Body; and see as many flourishing happy New Years, as your best and dearest Friends can desire; and every one add fresh Honours to those that are so deservedly worn by Your Grace at present, which are the earnest Wishes of

closer.signed: Your Grace's Most Obedient, and Most Devoted, Humble Servant, SUSANNA CENT-LIVRE.

div1.head: THE PREFACE.
div1.p:
I Shou'd not have troubled my Courteous Reader with a Preface, had I not lain under the Necessity of Clearing my self of what some People have been pleas'd to charge me with, viz. of being the Author of a Paper call'd, The Female Tattler, consequently of a Paragraph in that of the 14th Instant, relating to this Comedy; tho' I think no reasonable Person will believe I could be guilty of so much Folly. Tho' Vanity is said to be the darling Vice of Womankind, yet nothing but an Idiot wou'd express themselves so openly; and I hope the World won't think me guilty of Printing, what I must blush to Read, nor imagine it Wrote even by any Friend of mine, for two Reasons; First, the Grossness of the Flattery. Secondly, the Injury it must of course do me, in the Run of my Play, by putting those People out of Humour, whose Action was to give Life to the Piece. I suppose these Reasons are sufficient to convince the Judicious part, that I was no ways concerned in those Reflections, but own I was treated with all the seeming Civility in the World, till the second Night of my Comedy. I willingly submitted to Mr. Cibber's Superiour Judgment in shortning the Scene of the Ghost in the last Act, and believed him perfectly in the Right, because too
much Repetition is tiresome. Indeed when Mr. Estcourt slic'd most of it out, I cou'd not help interposing my Desires to the contrary, which the rest readily comply'd with; and I had the Satisfaction to see I was not deceiv'd in my Opinion, of its pleasing. This Passage I happen'd to mention among my Acquaintance; for 'tis Natural to have a kind of a Tender for our own Productions, but especially if they have the good Fortune to divert others. Now, if from this the Author of the Tattler gather'd his Account, I am guilty of speaking, but not designedly; for who they are that Write that Paper, or how Distinguish'd, I am perfectly ignorant, and declare I never was concern'd, either in Writing, or Publishing, any of the Tattlers.

I never had the Vanity to think, much less to publish, that any thing I am capable of doing, cou'd support the Stage, tho' I have had the good Fortune to please, or to find the Town willing to be pleas'd; tho' at present it seems a certain Author has enter'd a Caveat against all Plays running to a sixth Night, but his own. Tho' an Opera interfer'd with this Comedy, yet it brought above Forty Pounds the second Night, which shew'd it had some Merit; for I have known many a Play kept up, that fail'd of half that Money the second Night. Now by the Rules of the House, it ought to have been play'd on: But who can secure the Life of a Play, when that of a Man is often Sacrific'd to the Malice of Parties? This Play met with a kind Reception in general, and notwithstanding the Disadvantages it had to struggle with, by raising the Prices the first Day, and the Nearness of Christmas, it would have made its way to a sixth Night, if it had had fair Play. Mistake
me not, I do not mean from the Representation; for I must do the Players Reason: Had I search'd all the Theatres in the World, I cou'd not have selected a better Company, nor had more Justice done me in the Action, tho' they have not dealt honourably by me in my Bargain; for they ought not to have stop'd the Run, upon any Pique whatever. 'Tis small Encouragment to Write for the Stage, when the Actors, according to the Caprice of their Humours, mangre the Taste of the Town, have power to sink the Reputation of a Play; for if they resolve not to Act it, the Town can't support it.

Well, if there is any Merit in suffering wrongfully, I shall find my Account in't one time or other; in the mean while I intreat the Female Tattler to be Witty no more at my Expence. I desire I may not be rank'd in the Number of those that support the Stage, since the Stage is become a Noun Substantive, and resolves to shew it is able to stand by itself.

div1.head: PROLOGUE. By a GENTLEMAN. Spoken by Mr. WILKS.
div1.l: OUR Female Author trembling stands within,
Her Fear arises from another's Sin;
One of her Sex has so abus'd the Town,
That on her Score she dreads your angry Frown:
Tho' I dare say, poor Soul, she never writ
Lampoon, or Satyr on the Box or Pit;
A harmless hum'rous Play is her Extent of Wit.
Tho' Bickerstaff's vast Genius may engage,
And lash the Vice and Follies of the Age;
Why shou'd tender Delia tax the Nation?
Stickle, and make a Noise for Reformation,
Who always gave a Loose, her self, to Inclination.
Scandal and Satyr's thrown aside to Day,
And Humour the sole Business of our Play.
Beaux may dress on to catch the Ladies Hearts,
And good Assurance pass for mighty Parts:
The Citts may bring their Spouses without Fear,
We shew no Wife that's poaching for an Heir,
Nor teach the Use of fine Gause Handkercheir.
Cowards may huff, and talk of mighty Wonders,
And Jilts set up—for Twenty thousand Pounders.
Our Author, even tho' she knows full well,
Is so Good-natur'd, she forbears to tell
What Collonels, lately, have found out the Knack
To Muster Madam, still, by Ned, or Jack,
To keep their Pleasures up; a Frugal way,
They give her—Subaltern's Subsistance for her Pay.
In short, what e'er your Darling Vices are,
They pass untouch'd in this Night's Bill of Fare.
But if all this can't your good Nature wake,
Tho' here and there, a Scene shou'd fail to take,
Yet spare her for the Busie-Body's sake.

div1.head: EPILOGUE. Spoken by Mrs. OLDFIELD. Written by Mr. Cibber. A Porter delivers a Letter just as she is going to speak.
div1.l: WHAT's this? a Billet-Deaux? from Hands unknown?
'Tis new to send it thus 'fore all the Town:
But since the poor Man's Passion's so agog,
I'll read it out by way of Epilogue.

lg.l: Madam,
Permit a Wretch to let you know,
That he's no more in Statu Quo.
My Ruine from this Night commences,
Unless your Smiles refund my Senses;
For with one Thrust of Cupid's Dart,
You've whip'd your Slave quite thro' the Heart:
Therefore, I beg you, cast your Eye
O'er Boxes, Pit and Gallery,
In Pity of my Pains and Doubt,
And try if you can find me out.

div1.l: Poor Soul! He seems indeed in dismal Plight;
Let's see! it can't be, sure! from th' upper Flight;
No, no—that's plain—for —None of them can Write:
Nor can I think it from the Middle fell;
For I'm afraid—as few of them can Spell:
Beside, their Haggling Passions never gain,
Beyond the Passage-walking Nymphs of Drury-Lane:
And then the Pit's more stock'd with Rakes and Rovers,
Than any of these senseless, whining Lovers.
The Backs o' th' Boxes too seem mostly lin'd
With Souls, whose Passion's to themselves confin'd.
I sort, I can't perceive, 'mongst all you Sparks,
The Wretch distinguish'd, by these bloody Marks.
But since the Town has heard your kind Commands, Sir,
The Town shall e'en be Witness of my Answer.
First then, Beware you prove no Spark in Red,
With empty Purse, and Regimental Head;
That thinks no Woman can refuse t'engage in't,
While Love's advanc'd with offer'd Bills on Agent;
That swears he'll settle from his Joy's commencing,
And make the Babe, the Day he's Born, an Ensign.
Nor cou'd I bear a Titl'd Beau, that steals
From fasting Spouse her Matrimonial Meals;
That Modish sends next Morn to her Apartment,
A Civil How-deye—far alas! from th' Heart meant:
Then Powder'd for th' ensuing Day's Delights,
Bows thro' his Croud of Duns, and drives to White's.
Nor cou'd I like the Wretch, that all Night plays,
And only takes his Rest on Winning Days;
That sets up from a lucky Hit, his Rattler
Then's trac'd from his Orig'nal—in the Tattler.
To tell you all that are my fixt Aversion,
Wou'd tire the Tongue of Malice, or Aspersion.
But if I find 'mongst All One generous Heart,
That Deaf to Stories takes this Stage's Part;
That thinks that Purse deserves to keep the Plays,
Whose Fortune's bound for the Support of Opera's;
That thinks our Constitution here is justly fixt,
And now no more with Lawyers Brawls perplext.
He, I declare, shall my whole Heart receive;
And (what's more strange) I'll love him while I live.

set.p: SCENE, the Minster-yard in Peterborough. The Hour Six in the Morning.

div2.stage: Enter Captain Constant and Clinch in Mourning, with Riding Habit over it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: CLinch! Where are you Sirrah? Why don't you come along?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah! Pox of this riding Post,—Look ye, Captain; if you have threescore Miles farther to go, I am your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, I am at my Journey's end—This Town of Peterborough is the bound of all my Wishes.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir! Pray be pleas'd to make it mine too.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why! what is your wish?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Why, with submission, Sir, to know the reason of your Expedition, and gravity of Habit: Have you a mind to set up the Business of an Undertaker here in the Country?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No, Clinch, my business is with the Living, not with the Dead, I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Then can't I for my blood imagine why you are thus dress'd; your Father, nay your whole Family are well; not so much as a Nephew, or second Cousin dead; nay, nor no fear of Peace.——Then why the Devil are we in black? You laugh—Can these Cloaths cause Joy, without the Perquisite that belongs to it: 'Tis a mournful Equipage, and shocks my Soul, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Perquisite! Why what Perquisite does Mourning bring with it to cause Joy? ha!

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir, several—As when a Wife buries her Husband, she has Sorrow in one hand, and Joy in t'other; a short Widowhood cures such a Grief—Or a rich Heir at the last Gasp of his Parent, when there is a Years Rent in the Steward's
hands —But, Sir, to the point; either let me into the Secret, or discharge me.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; Why then if I must tell thee; this Habit, if Fortune favours me, will be worth to me two thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir; and pray how much will it be worth to me? For I am dress'd like you—If I have not the same Privileges, why should I be confin'd to the same Garb?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh! you shall have your part, Clinch, never fear.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, but there are some parts I don't care for—— I hope you have no design to rob upon the Highway.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Rascal!

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, ben't angry Sir; if there shou'd be Peace, 'tis what many an honest Gentleman must come to. I have no aversion for the Name; but I have for the Punishment— I'll not strike a stroke—therefore what good can I do you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I shall have more occasion for your Eyes, than your Arm—You can weep, Sirrah, can't you?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, I shall weep, that's certain, to see you come to the Gallows—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ye Dog you, I tell you there is no danger.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: No danger—Why then I shall weep for Joy, Sir— —but how, Sir, how; must I roar, or shed Tears?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: So you do but counterfeit well, no matter which.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah, let me alone for counterfeiting, I defie a Woman to out-do me in that—Look ye Sir, you shall hear — —hem, hem. Roars out.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Very well—be sure when I weep—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I'll make terrible Faces—What think you; Sir, Is not my Pipe very musical for weeping?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh! Excellent.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: But what does this signifie! Where lies the Mystery?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Well then—Since you must know it; You are not insensible how my Father has treated me, ever since I refus'd to marry Mrs. Homebred, whose Manners suited with her Name, and her Face was courser than either; and because I drew a Bill upon him for fifty Pounds last Campaign, he threatens to disinherit me; nay, and swears, that if for the future I don't make it appear I live upon half my Pay, He'll
make my Serjeant his Heir, who was once his Footman. In short, I can bear his ill usage no longer.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, had you married that Lady with twenty thousand Pounds, you need not have drawn upon him for fifty.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: If she had twenty times as much, I shou'd refuse her for Belinda's sake.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: But Sir Jeffrey resolves against that Match—You must not marry his Steward's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I hope to prove you a Lyar, Sir; and by this Dress to carry my design; which is to persuade Trusty, that my Father dyed of an Apoplexy, by which means he must account with me for the half Years Rent, he sent the old Gentleman word was ready for him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Two thousand Pound, Clinch—This Letter I surpriz'd by an Accident; 'tis from my Father to him. Reads.

Mr. Trusty,
The several Sums which you have return'd me without any Receipt, amounts to eight hundred Pounds, there remains behind two thousand two hundred Pounds, which you tell me is ready for me; don't give your self any trouble about remitting that, for I design to be down my self in a Fortnight; and then the Leases which you mention'd, shall be renew'd. You need write no more, till you see
Your real Friend Jeffrey Constant.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Excellent, Sir! Why here may be a pretty Penny towards, if the Devil don't cross it. But, Sir, if my old Master shou'd take a Maggot, and write to Trusty, to return his Money after all—His Letter and our Story wou'd have small connexion; we shou'd be oblig'd to alter our Note. I wou'd advise you to take the old Steward to the Tavern, and stay as little in his House as you can, for fear of discovery: Besides, Sir, a Glass of Wine and a Fowl, makes business go on chearfully, Sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Chearfully, Sirrah!—You don't consider that it is not my business to be chearful—I admire Faithful stays so long.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Perhaps he can't find Mr. Lovely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I directed him to the Coffee-house, where he seldom fails to be at this time of the Morning.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman! I warrant he's ruminating upon his Misfortunes. Well! 'tis sometimes a Blessing to want Money— —You 'scap'd the Highway-men, Sir!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What am I the better for that, Sirrah? My Pockets are as empty as my Friends, who fell into their Hands: But here comes my Fellow Traveller—and Lovely with him; He has found him at last— Dear Lovely, how is't?

div2.stage: Enter Lovely, Faithful, and Manage, in Riding habit.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Captain Constant! Welcome! Who expected to see you here? Why did t you send me word of your coming?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: He hardly knew it himself two hours before he got on Horseback, Sir; nay, I much question if he knows it yet.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My Journey indeed was something Precipitate.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, don't you see we are in Mourning?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mr. Faithful has inform'd me of every Particular; and I wish I cou'd really give thee Joy of six thousand a Year, Boy.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: At the rate of half a Years Rent you may—If Fortune proves not an errand Jilt indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen; What think you of my House? I'll get something for Breakfast, whilst you change your Linen.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis near Six—I have a mind to see if Belinda comes to Church this Morning.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: She seldom fails—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Prithee, Lovely; Can you inform me, if a young Lady that lives at Sir David Watchum's will be here too?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mrs. Laura Wealthy, Your Mistress you mean.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: We have heard of the Lady; but I believe no body in Peterborough has seen her, except his own Servants.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What kind of a temper is the old Fellow of?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
The most peevish, splenetick, mistrustful, ill-natur'd Wretch in the whole County: He comes to the Coffee-house every Morning in an old rusty Chariot for haste, the longest Journey
he takes in the Year: He seldom comes to Church; nay, since that Lady came he has not once been seen there; we fancy he dares not stay two hours from home, for fear she should be stol'n away.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, this account is most uncomfortable in our Affairs—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: It gives me more Chagrin, than the Rogues did, when they stripp'd me of my Money this Morning— Which way shall I give Laura notice of my being in Town?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Have Courage, Faithful, I warrant we prosper.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nothing like a good Heart; you shall not want a small Sum of Money, Sir.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I'll be as diligent in thy Affairs, as in my own— if any lucky Opportunity offers, I'll be ready to serve thee.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'll be the same to both.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I know it; and when I am able; as I hope if my design succeeds, thou shal't meet returns in me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to both—But who have we here?

div2.stage: Several People cross the Stage to Church.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Here comes Belinda, and with her my Tyrant Maria.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen; you'll best entertain your Mistresses alone; I'll back to the Coffee-house, and over a Dish of Tea think what Course to steer—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Mind if the Courant be there, wherein I got my Father's Death inserted, the better to favour my Plot.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I will, Captain, and be sure to confirm the News.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: We'll call of you there presently—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But is Maria obdurate still Lovely?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not in reality, Constant—But she has so much of the Woman in her, to keep up her Rule till the last.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ladies, good morrow! The sound of the Saint's Bell brings Angels abroad. Salutes 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Constant! and in Mourning! Pray who's dead?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: One for whom I ought to grieve, did it not smooth a Passage to Belinda's Arms, through the Hearts of our inexorable Parents.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Father! Sir.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: The same, Madam! He's as dead as an Herring, I promise you—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now don't I know, whether I had best say I'm sorry for your Loss, or wish you much Joy of your Gain.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I dare swear, Madam, he can't tell you yet.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Peace, Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mr. Lovely, are you for Prayers?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You are the Shrine he kneels to, Madam; if you'll vouchsafe to hear him, he can pray most devoutly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And dissemble most fervently—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No faith, Madam, that Quality does not belong to us—that is the Womens Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And do you never encroach upon our Privileges, sweet Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, yes faith; I have encroach'd upon some of the Sexes Privileges in my time, I must own. Curiosity— Madam, seldom leads us to put on Masking Habits; but a Lady cannot dress without 'em; Dissimulation is as necessary as her Patches.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay! How do you prove that?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why thus: When you wou'd gain a Man you like, you appear what you are not—We believe you Angels, but don't always find you so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We always find you Angels, but of the fal'n kind.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible to be otherwise, whilst Beauty keeps her Court below, you charm our Eyes, and all our Senses wait you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pride and Vanity predominate in your Sex, and like Centinels relieve one another; Pride has made a Lady swear she has Hated such a Man, tho' she was dying for the Sight of him—And Vanity made her Caress a Fop, that at the same time she wish'd at the Devil.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
And are not you even with us? Will not you sigh, ogle, cringe, flatter, swear, kneel, nay give it under your hand, you Love to desperation; but let the poor mistaken
Nymph once yield, and you'd give Bond and Judgment to that Old Gentleman you nam'd but now, in two Days to take her off your hands.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I hope you don't include the whole Sex, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That she do's not, I'm sure; for she knows I never swore any thing to her, but what I am ready to make good— And if she be not the most unconscionable Woman living, she will own I love her heartily.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: That I dare witness for thee, Lovely.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay! Why, what Proofs has he given?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Proofs! Why I talk of her all Day—And dream, of her all Night——When she's absent, sigh for her, and am transported when I see her. If these be not proofs of Love, let the Parson say Grace and I'll give her better.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: All this may be done without one Grain of Love, may it not Captain?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Not when you are the Object, Madam; and you are too well acquainted with my Heart, to ask that Question out of scruple, I'm certain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: These are no Proofs; you must grow Lean and Meagre—Eat little, and Sleep less—Write fifty Letters in a Day, and burn them all again—Then start up, and draw your Sword; hold it to your Breast; then throw it away agen — Then take your Pen and write your last Farewel—Dispatch it to your Mistress—Then take a Turn by some melancholy purling Stream, with Hat pull'd o'er your Eyes, in deep Contemplation resolve thro' what Door to let in Death, if the Messenger return without Success—When I see you do this, I'll write Lover upon your Brow.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: When I do, you shall write Fool upon my Forehead.
sp.l: Hang this whining way of Wooing,
Loving was design'd a Sport, &c.Sings.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come, come Madam, a Truce; you know he loves you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: As well as I know she loves me; we were born for one another, Child; no Man in the Kingdom shall have thee, but my self.—Then if you will eat Chalk, and die of the Pip, I can't help it. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Be not so positive Lovely.—One Sect of Philosophers tells you, you ought to doubt of every thing.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But the Topick was not a Woman in that Assertion; but if it were, Women in their Days were no more like Women in ours, than a Clodhopper is to a Captain o' Foot. Our Ladies are like two Negatives, to be understood in the Affimative, ha, ha. Madam, do's not my Friend here look like one of those Lovers you describ'd? Faith, I think a Woman cannot wish a simpler Figure—Now has he a thousand Things to say to Belinda alone.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You guess right, Lovely—I am going to your Father's, Madam, to settle our Accounts; I hope you'll return as soon as Prayers are over.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Directly—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Oh Belinda!
Now is the Crisis of our Good or Ill;
Turn for me, Fate, or let thy Wheel stand still.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You'll remember us in your Prayers, Ladies——

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Amongst Jews, Turks and Infidels— Exit.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come, now for my House—We'll call on Faithful.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Lead on—I'll change my Linen and to Trusty's immediately—But hold—Clinch, heark yee.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I had no Opportunity to inform Belinda of my Project; you must away to Trusty's and let her Maid into the Secret, I wou'd not impose upon her—The Man that truly Loves, cannot deceive the Object of his Vows.
sp.l: He never felt the Force of Cupid's Dart,
Who lets his Tongue run counter to his Heart;
Or ever can deserve the Charming Maid,
That is by Falshood to his Arms betray'd.
For mutual Passions in all States agree,
And lines the Yoke with true Felicity.
She shall my Project with my Love compare.
If she approves it, I'm indeed an Heir.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Or at the worst, we are but as we were.

div2.stage: Enter 'Squire Num, and his Man Slouch.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p:
What think you Slouch! Had we best go into the Minster, or tarry here whilst Mrs. Belinda comes out; for her Maid says she's here: Lord, Lord, how Religious Folk
are in this Town! Why they rise as early to Church here, as our Parson's Wife does to Milking, I think—Well, but what had we best to do, ha?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Why go in, I think—Or tarry here; which you will, Master.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Nay, nay mun, I don't know which is best, that makes me ask you; for I know, Slouch, you understand Breeding and Haviours; for you have been at London with fat Bullocks, and so was never I; but I resolve to go next time, ha! Slouch!

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Ay Master; but an you Marry this same Mrs. Belinda, as sure as your Name is 'Squire Num, she'll not let you budge a Step.

sp.speaker: Num,
sp.p: Marry her! Nay, nay, I shall Marry her, that's sure enough, I think; and yet I'll see London for all that— Why, what dost thou think I'll be ty'd to a Wife's Tail all Days o' my Life? No, no; the Family of the Nums won't be Wife-rid, Slouch—But heark yee, an her Father shou'd chop up the Wedding to Day, before my New Cloathes are made; for he likes me woundily mun.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Od well thought on Master! don't go into the Church, I say; who knows but when the Parson has done his Prayers, but he may begin your Plagues, Master ha!

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Od that's smart now—Ha, ha, hush, hush, Slouch, they are here—Now show your Manners—

div2.stage: Enter Trusty, Belinda and Maria. Several others cross the Stage as from Church.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I have met a Report in the Church, that the News says Sir Jeffry Constant is Dead; if it be true, there's a better Husband for Belinda than this Fool—Od! I'll for London as soon as I have Din'd; my Heart akes; pray Heaven he settled his Affairs before he died: I have no Receipt for the Money I paid him.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p:
Sir, your Servant; Father has sent me agen to see Mrs. Belinda, and bid me tell you, That he wou'd come over himself, I think, next Week, an do what you wou'd have him do, I think—And so, I suppose, we are agreed, forsooth ——Only I must desire you to stay till my New Cloathes
are made. Father bought the Cloth last Sturbich Fair; and the Taylor comes to Morrow, don't he Slouch?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Ay, and his Man Staytape too; an he works like a Dragon—My Master will soon be fit, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fit quotha! for what? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: For what! nay, nay, let me alone for that, an I don't show her for what, when I have her once, I'll be flea'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Heaven defend me from the Tryal.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir, since I saw you last, I have consider'd my Daughter is no proper Match for you; and therefore I desire you to return with all possible Speed, and acquaint your Father, that he may not undertake an unnecessary Journey.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ten thousand Blessings on that Voice.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: High day: What's the matter now! Why you don't pretend to make a Fool of me, do ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, thou art made to his hands—ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Who speaks to you Mistress, I was not made for you I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, I thank my Stars!

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: I'll not be chous'd at this rate, mun: Did you not tell me, if my Father wou'd settle so, and so, that I shou'd have her—And now you come with a Consider— when it has cost me the Lord knows what in Journeys, as Slouch can testifie.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Yes, with a safe Conscience, I can swear it has cost my Master—and me, above Thirty Shillings upon you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What did you Club with your Master then, Mr. Slouch?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Now and then, for a Flagon of Ale, an it please you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh you shall be no Loser, Friend—There's something to defray your Expences— gives him Money.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Thank you kindly, Forsooth—Od, this 'tis to be Sharp—Now wou'd I give Sixpence to know if this be a good Guinea, or a Counter— aside.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: As to your Charges, Mr. Num—If you please to give me a Bill, they shall be discharg'd—But for my Daughter, I have design'd her otherways.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p:
A Bill! I scorn your Words; I'm as well able, de you see, to spend Thirty Shillings as you, for ought I know; yet I'm not angry neither; only what makes me mad, is, that you shou'd think me such a Fool to be fob'd off I know not
how—Why mun, all our Town knows that I'm to have her, and they have promis'd me the Bells shou'd Ring a whole Day—And now you'd have me go home with the Tale of a Tub, like a Dog that has lost his Ears—What did you come bouncing to our House for! and say I shou'd have your Daughter—I did not come after her, nor you neither mun.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: What I said I thought at that time, Sir; but no Man can blame me for changing my Mind to Advantage in disposing of my Child— I have a better Prospect both in Birth and Estate, than you, or your Father can offer. Therefore I say without any Passion, I desire you'd give your self no farther Trouble about this matter, Mr. Num.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Birth, and Estate! What means my Father? how I tremble!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He has certainly heard of Sir Jeffry's Death, and designs to make thee Happy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Impossible! He was in the Minster before us.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Birth, and Estate! Slouch, come hither Sirrah! han't my Father a Thousand a Year?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Yes that he has, an more too: He has Ten hundred, I'll swear it.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: I believe he has, as you say, Slouch.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: An I am all the Children he has, am I not, Slouch?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Ay, all that he dares own, Sir.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Look ye there now! An I'll hold you a Bottle of Cyder that I'm as well born as he; my Father's Church-warden and Captain of the Militia, as 'tis known very well; and I'm call'd the Young Captain, so I am.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Aye, that every Body knows.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir, I have nothing to say to that, and am your humble Servant—Come Belinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I wish you a good Journey, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Captain, your Servant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: A murrain take your Fleer ——

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: You may go to London now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Go to London, go to the Devil! 'Slife I'll follow them mun, mehap he do's but joke; and Father will break my Head, because I did not understand a Joke— Therefore come along, Slouch— Exit.

div2.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div2.stage: Enter Sir David into a Garden before the Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I Have survey'd my House round and round to Night, from Door to Door, and Gate to Gate— —He that wou'd keep a handsome Woman of Twenty thousand Pound, must learn the Gamester's Art, to live without Sleep—Methought, from my Garret Window, I saw a Man sauntring about my Ground, and seem'd to pry too narrowly into my House—It may be a Rogue—I would not lose Mrs. Laura; for, if possible, she shall fill no Arms but mine. I have kept her from the sight of Man these twelve Months; and now I design to offer her Liberty, provided she'll consent to be my Wife; if she refuses, I'll have the Lights quite stop'd up, and she shall not so much as see the Sun—Ha! who's here! Ho, 'tis Lucy, her Maid; I wish I cou'd make this Jade of my Interest—What the Vengeance do's she do up so early?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: This old Fellow is certainly the Devil—One can go no where, but one is sure to meet him.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What makes you here, ha Mistress?—Now am I afraid of venturing to the Coffee-House, tho' my Coach is at the Door.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Too much Sleep is unwholsome, you know Sir, by your own Rule; so hearing the Door open, I came down to breath the Morning Air.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: That you might have done at your Window; no, no, you have some Plot in hand now I warrant! Where's your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: In her Chamber. Where shou'd she be?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: In her Bed wou'd be a fitter Place—Women of Virtue, that have no Intrigues, are fast asleep in their Beds at this time a-day

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: A sleep! That's impossible in this House—Pray how can any body seep, as long as you are awake; are you not rambling all Night; up Stairs, down Stairs, locking one Door, and opening another; heming, coughing, spitting, sneezing, yawning, stamping, mutt'ring—One no sooner shuts ones Eyes—but slap goes a Door, clatter goes a Key— down tumbles a Stool, bow wow goes the Dog—This is the constant Musick you make, Sir: 'Slife, if one were a Slave in Turkey, one shou'd sometimes rest in quiet.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Good lack, good lack, all this I get for my care— —Why all this is for your Lady's good, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, if you call this Good! Then pray Sir employ your Study for the future, to do her ill Offices; for nothing can be more disagreeable, than your present treatment both to my Lady and me.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Say you so! What, you don't like your way of living then? ha.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Not at all I assure you, Sir—Living! d'ye call it—We wou'd have Liberty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: You shall have Liberty, if your Lady is not her own Enemy——and for your part, if you please, you may serve your self, and her, by being serviceable to me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Which way, pray Sir? For there is not many things I wou'd refuse to procure my Lady, her dear, dear Liberty; pray inform me, I'm impatient to know it.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why thus—I have a very Cordial Affection for Mrs. Laura, out of pure Consideration of her youth—I wou'd not have a young Woman fall into ill hands at first; therefore I design to marry her my self.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Heaven forbid! that wou'd be falling into ill hands indeed. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Now I wou'd have you break this matter to her; and second it with all the force of Argument you are capable of—When we are married, you shall both take what Liberty you please.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why sure a Person of your experienc'd Years, wou'd not be guilty of such a Folly.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you call Folly? I had no Chldren by my last Wife, and I wou'd willingly have an Heir to keep up my Name—and do you call this Folly?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Heirs! Why do you hope for an Heir of your own getting, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why not, pray?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What, upon such a fine Woman as she is—In my Conscience, were I in your place, I shou'd dread being the errantest, you know what, in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Mrs. Pert! that's not your business, I shall dread no such thing—All I desire of you, is to tell her, my Estate, Prudence, Wisdom and Temperance, out-weighs Youth, Folly, Titles, and Debauchery.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, for one that is in Love with her Grave. Certainly, Sir, you are not in your right Senses—Why your Request is so abominable, so vile, so ridiculous, and so unjust; that I wou'd not be concern'd in it for a thousand Pounds— Indeed you have pitch'd upon the wrong Person, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Dav.
sp.p: Say you so! Good lack—So I have pitch'd upon the wrong Person you say! ha! If I had desir'd you to say your Prayers, I'll be hang'd, if I had not pitch'd upon the wrong Person too, Gossip prate apace—but I'll hamper ye, I warrant you; I'll cross your Designs, till I have finish'd my own —go, get out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, surely this Life won't last always. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: My Master stays at the Coffee-house, and has sent me to survey this Dome, and try to give Mrs. Laura's Maid notice of his Arrival; but how far I may be serviceable to him, I know not—Ha! who have we yonder? The old Guardian himself I doubt—So, he has found me—What the duce must I pretend now?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you want Friend, ha?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Good morrow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, Good morrow; what more?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I hope you are well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Yes, thank Heaven, Sir! what then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why then I am very glad of it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: You are very glad of it, Sir! Why what a Pox is my Health to you? Who are you? What are you? And from whence come you, ha Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, your Questions are so copious, that they require a considerable Study to answer: let me recollect a little—I have gone through so many Trades, that without my Diary (which I have not about me at present) I can't remember half of them; nor indeed can I tell how to stile my self otherwise than an universal Man —The World is my Country; and for want of an Estate, I live by my Wits—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: A Rogue, I warrant him. Aside.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sometimes an honest Man, sometimes a Knave; just as occasions fall out.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ay! and you oftner happen to be a Knave, than an honest Man, I doubt, Friend.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why look ye, Sir, that is just as I abound, or want Money; for my present Profession is Physick—Now when my Pockets are full, I cure a Patient in three Days— —when they are empty, I keep him three Months.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: An excellent Principle truly—But pray what is your business at my House?—We are all in a good state of health at present.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay no very great business, only I look'd in, as I pass'd by, Sir, that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Now in my Opinion you have another Reason; for you have the Aspect of one of those Sparks that comes in at a Window, or down a Chimney at two in the Morning—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have a care what you say, Sir, I'm known very well not far off.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ay, too well perhaps! Zounds, Sir, what business have you here, speak.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A queer old Duke this—Why, Sir, if you must know, I am in search of some Simples which I have occasion for—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Simples!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Simples! A very simple Excuse, saith—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, I have many Years practis'd Chymistry, and there's scarce any Disease incident to Humanity, but I have cur'd; Stone, Gravel, Spleen, Vapours, fits of the Mother, and so forth—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Rather Fits of the Father, I fancy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I had attain'd to such perfections in the Chymical Art, that I wanted but one degree of heat to reach the Philosopher's Stone.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: That Habit methinks does not answer this mighty Skill.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, Skill does not lie in Cloaths—And the most ingenuous, are not always the most fortunate— I have had many Crosses in my time—Which has reduc'd me much below my Birth, I assure you—I serve an Officer at present, in the Quality of a Valet de Chambre, whose Life I sav'd at the Battle of Audenard, when he was shot through with a Cannon Ball.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: How! shot through with a Cannon Ball?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; what, do you wonder at that? Why, Sir, I have a Water, that if your Head were off, I'd but wash it with that, and clap it upon your Shoulders again; and you shou'd grow as perfectly well in half an hour, as ever you was in your Life; I have made the Experiment upon Thousands; my Master's Brother was one of them—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: If you were in Petticoats, I shou'd take you for the Kentish Miracle—What is this Officer's Name, Friend, that you serve?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Captain Bounce, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Bounce! I fancy you are related to him, are you not, Friend?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, Sir, not at all; indeed he uses me more like a Relation, than a Servant, for the reason before mentioned.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ha! And where is he, pray?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: At the Talbot, Sir; if you please I'll fetch him hither?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: By no means, Sir; but what business have you here in Peterborough?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We have been raising Recruits, Sir—A Pox of this old Dog; how many impertinent Questions does he ask— Here's no hopes of seeing Lucy—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I desire you'd look your Simples elsewhere; for I don't like you, notwithstanding your fair Pretences.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, I shall obey you—But pray who does this House belong to?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why, this House belongs to —its Master.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir——Pray who is that Master? if I may be so bold to ask.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why that Master is—a Man Friend.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Really, Sir, your Answers are so concise and so ingenious, that it is impossible to quit your Company——We design for Cambridge to Night, pray what time do you think we shall get in?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav,
sp.p: The Town Clock will tell you, when you come there.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Is it possible!—I humbly thank you, Sir—— one thing more I wou'd gladly be resolv'd—I have a Brother bound for Portugal; pray is the Wind fair, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you take me for, a Weather Cock, Sirrah? Heark ye, the Wind will blow you no good, if you don't get about your business, remember that, and so farewel. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very well——this must be Sir David his own self— —'Egad he has all his Paces, it will be hard to bring matters about here; I'm just as wise as I was when I came—and have told fifty Lyes to no purpose——Ha! his Coach at the Door, I'll watch whither he goes, I'm resolv'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What, are you not gone yet, Sirrah? I'll have you laid by the Heels, if you don't get off my ground this moment.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, I am going this moment—A Pox of his Leathern Jaws —Well, I'll inform my Master what has pass'd, and leave him to think on what's to come— Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: So, he is gone—I don't like the Countenance of this Fellow—Sam—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Lock my Doors, d'ye hear; till I return from
the Coffee-house, let no body in or out—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I shall observe, Sir. Ex. severally.

head.stage: SCENE Changes to the Coffee-house, Lovely, Constant, and Faithful.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I have confirm'd the whole Town in the belief of thy Father's Death.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Then thou hast done me Service—Come, you'll both go with me to Trusty's—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: No, I have a mind to stay here; to see if Sir David comes; this Morning I will try to get acquainted with him; perhaps my being a Stranger, he may invite me to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, He wou'd as soon give thee his Estate.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! Manage, what News? Hast thou seen Lucy?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, Sir, but I have seen the Knight.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, and what have you discover'd?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That it was not worth your while to come Post from London, to return the same way—Ah Pox of the last Horse I rid; what a cursed Fall had I in Stangate-hole— —don't you remember, Sir, how I lay over Head and Ears in Mire; whilst the Gentlemen of the Pad disburthen'd you of a hundred Pounds?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Hang your unseasonable Memory, Sirrah; leave fooling, and tell me—You see Sir David, did you speak to him?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but he answer'd me with a damn'd sowre Air; and I assure you it will require Cannon to reduce his Cittadel.

sp.speaker: Faith,
sp.p: Love has taught me to surmount all Difficulties.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But here the Knight will be immediately; for I heard him give Orders to lock up the Doors, till he return'd from the Coffee-house.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ay, that's right Sir David! ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Lock up the Doors! Ah poor Laura! how shall I give thee notice of my being here—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
I have a thought in my Head, if it cou'd be put in
practice——Heark, I hear the Coach——had here's no b¦dy in the Room to discover the Trick——Let as pretend a Quarrel——Draw, Faithful.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: To what purpose?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You shall know instantly——Lovely, do you seem to part us; he's here——Damn you Sir, you Lye. draws. I have not lost, nor will I pay——

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Take your Lye back, Sir, seem to fight.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, Gentlemen; what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Damn you, Sir, you shall pay me—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: There is the Money then, you have it——pretend to be wounded with that Thrust, Faithful.Aside to him.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am wounded——pray help to lead me home—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh Friend! what have you done?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What's here, Murder?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I hope the Wound's not mortal——Curse on my unlucky Arm; how dost thou, Ned?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Do quotha! If the Gentleman is wounded, I must secure you, Sir,

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Secure me, Sir! Alas! Sir, I don't intend to fly; a Pox of all Wagers I say.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Pray lead me to my Inn, for I feel my Spirits very faint.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Lead you! Alas, I doubt you cannot walk so far.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What, is there not a Chair or a Coach to be got?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir David has a Coach at the Door, if you cou'd prevail with him to lend it you a little.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sir, pray oblige us with your Coach, it shall return immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: With all my heart— Goes to the Door, and speaks to his Coachman aloud.
Tom, Here, carry this Gentleman home—d'ye hear, and make haste back again,

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Oh! Friend, I understand you now; my Soul dances with the bare Idea.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: It has succeeded to my Wish—Lovely, help ld him to the Coach.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: If there be any Danger, Mr. Lovely, take care to secure the Murderer.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh! They are intimate Friends, Sir David, he won't flinch, I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, well, look you to that— Ex. into the House.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Manage! Come you along with us, I have some Instructions for you. Exeunt.

head.stage: SCENE Changes to the out side of Trusty's House.

div2.stage: Enter Lovely, Constant, Clinch and Manage.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He'll certainly get admittance to his Mistress by this Stratagem; but if the Knight shou'd find him there, how will he come off?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, let him look to that—but Manage shall take Clinch's great Coat, 'tis like a Livery—Sweet Sir, can you condescend to wear a Livery an hour or two?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To serve my Master's Amour I will, Sir—else I scorn a Livery—. I must have that black Wig too.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well, well! Here, Clinch, change, change with him. they change Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: So, Sir! Now I am your Valet de Chambre.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what am I to do now?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why, go watch about Sir David's Door, and as you see occasion, employ your Wits.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, let me alone for that; your humble Servant, Gentlemen. Exit.

div2.stage: Enter Dolly, out of the House.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Oh! Are you come Captain; I have told my Mistress every particular—please to walk in, Sir, I'll inform my Master you are here. They go in.

head.stage: The SCENE draws, and discovers them in a Room.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis an admirable Project, Captain, if you are not discover'd; but your Father will certainly know it in a little time.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: If possible, I'll marry the Woman to Night.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I fear Sir Jeffrey will resent the Trick.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I hope to convince him the Trick was upon Trusty; for he may recover the Money of him, if he pleases, and with me it may pass for his Daughter's Portion; but rather than fail, I'll give the Steward my Bond, when 'tis discover'd, to refund the Money, when I become Master of my Father's Estate; for without Belinda, nothing can make me Happy.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, you'll scarce find a Man in the Army of your Mind—Prefer a Woman to Money! Why Sir, Money is the very Hinge the whole World turns upon——A Soldier, and not love Money!—Money has power to alter all Constitutions, and in spight of Custom, stamp what Form it pleases—'Twill make an honest Man a Knave; nay, 'twill make a Knave an honest Man—'Twill make a Coward Valiant—an Old Woman Young——a Young Woman a Saint ——a Lawyer Just—a Statesman Loyal——and a Courtier keep his Word.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Clinch is a Wit.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Faith, I always thought so by my Poverty.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well hinted Clinch——I'm in thy Debt——

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I'm yours in all respects—Oh! this dear Colour!
sp.l: What can there be that this dear Coin can't buy?
For thee Men toil and sweat, swear, cheat and lye;
For thee do's Friend his dearest Friend betray,
And Women give their very Souls away.
Joyn but Ambition to this glitt'ring Evil,
And in an Instant Man is made a Devil.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ha, ha. ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ad's heart, Sir, set your weeping Face in Order— Here comes the Steward—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Captain Constant, your Servant! you are welcome into the Country. What, you are in want of Men; I warrant you are going to raise Recruits.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Not at this time, Sir; 'tis a more unwelcome Accident that brought me down. takes out his Handkerchief, and seems to weep.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Good lack! the News is really true then, Sir Jeffry is Dead.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, poor Gentleman, he's laid low—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I confess I heard so, but I hop'd it might be Report only; I did design to have set out for London as soon as I had Dn'd—My Heart akes—Bless me! What have I paid him without any Receipt—I lov'd Sir Jeffry like a Brother; truly I am very much troubled— seems to weep.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Grief is very catching, I find; it makes me weep too —Be comforted, Sir to Constant. Fathers must go as well as Sons—Why do you afflict your self at this ate, Sir? Since Death is Death, who can help it?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pray be comforted, Sir John— to Constant.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Pray of what Distemper did he die?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah! duce on't! What was that hard Word? Now can't I think on't, as I hope to be Great—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Of an Apoplexy—A Pox of the Doctors, for giving Death so many strange Names. aside.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Right, Sir—He died of Apoplexy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Of an Apoplexy! Why then I doubt he died suddainly.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: In a Moment's time, Sir, he was alive and dead—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, without ever speaking one Word, Sir —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Roars out. Oh, oh, oh. Did he settle his Affairs in his Health? Did he make any Will?—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Not any, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: No, Sir: He has left all at sixes and sevens.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh— faints.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! Help, Clinch, I hope he is not Dead.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: No, no; he breaths, thank Heaven; pray you look up, Sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why are you thus concern'd?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You really increase Sir John's Grief, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh what have I lost!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I know you have lost a Friend in my Father; but you shall find him again in me.

sp.speaker: Tru,
sp.p: Oh but he has left all things at fixe and ses, Clinch says—Did he say nothing to you about me before he dy'd?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Not a Syllable—But I suppose your Concern proceeds from having paid him Mney without any thin show for it under his hand.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, there's my Misfortune— Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: 'Tis the Money, not the Man—Let not that trouble you, Sir, my young Master has been inform'd to a Farthing what it was —Tell him, tell him, Sir, your Father appear'd, and let me alone to clinch it. aside to Constant.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Inform'd!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes Mr. Trusty; my Father cou'd not rest till had disclos'd your Affair.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah good honest Soul; seeing he was snatch'd away so suddainly he has several times appear'd.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How! appear'd, say you?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ask my Master else.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Most certain, Sir—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: He haunted us six Days like the Devil; sometimes like a shag Dog—Sometimes like a white Pidgeon —At last he took his own Shape. Clinch, said he, don't you know me? Then addressing himself to my Master; don't be afra, said he, I come to tell you, that at several times I have ¦ceiv'd from Mr. Trusty.—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ah dear Ghost, dear Ghost; how much did he say

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Eight hundred Pound.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Right to a Penny, look ye there now, see what it is to deal with honest Men; one loses nothing by them, tho' their Graves.

sp.speaker: Clin,
sp.p: Oh, the Dead, Sir, are always Generous; they value Money no more than that— snapping his Fingers.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman, that he shou'd take a Journey sic the other World upon my account.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, the Dead ride post upon the Winds— He charg'd me to tell you, for your Satisfaction, he woud come and give you an Acquittance himself.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By no means, I am content, let the Dead visit wh they will for me.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh fear not, Sir, he'll not trouble you; but to out Business, Sir, what you have paid I will discount.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And the rest of the Money is at your Service, and my Daughter too, Sir John, if you have not lost the Remembrance of her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: To show you that I have not, Mr. Trusty, I assure you she will be the welcomest Present of the two.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Thy Business is done, Constant.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir John! Well, I'll fetch the Writings, and dispatch some Affairs, and then I'll carry you to my Daughter—But upon second Thoughts, please to walk into my Study, 'tis more convenient.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: With all my Heart, I'll follow you— Exit Trusty.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Matters go as you cou'd wish; you'll be Married to Night, Captain.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I wish 'twere over; Egad I'd rather fight half a dozen Men, than descend to this Rascally way of Lying, were there any help for i, it is beneath a Soldier—
sp.l: A Soldier scorns the whining Lover's Art;
His Courage takes Possession of the Heart:
Disdains by Treachery to raise his Name,
But boldly owns the bright ambitious Flame,
And courts his Mistress as he courts his Fame.

div2.stage: Trusty in his Study, with Constant, Lovely and Clinch. Papers and Money upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: THere, Sir John, there are in these Bags Two and twenty hundred Pound, which, with the Eight hundred I remitted Sir Jeffry, is just Three thousand Pound; if you please you may count it, 'tis most in Gold.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No, I'll take your Word frt here, to Drive the Carrier, he is just now going to ; Ord him where to pay it in, d'ye heat?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—— Exit with the Bags.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He is loaden with it, ha, ha, ha.——

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Poor Sir Jeffry, rest his Soul, did promise to hae me Twenty Pound a Year; for I have paid him Two hundred Pounds a Year these sixteen Years, for that Land which is not worth an Hundred and fourscore.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Say you so, Mr. Trusty? Then you must perform your Father's Promise, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ay, when he has paid me as much as he has my F¦ther.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come, shall I settle Matters between you? Advance Sir John a Hundred Pounds; you know he has been kept short, and doubtless s casion for ready Money, and he shall 'bate you Twenty Pound a Year.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh, that's all one, Mr. Lly——I can't do that.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, since Mr. Lovely has propos'd it, if you won't do that—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, but Sir John, perhaps you'll expect a large Fortune with my Daughter; I can't tell how to——

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I ask you for none, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why then there's the Hundred Pound; but you must signifie at the bottom of this Lease our Bargain.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Give it me, I'll do't— sits down to write.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Morrow Landlord, I ha' brought you a little Rent, and in froth 'tis but a little neither; for we ha' had but sorr Crop of Barley, and the Crows, a murrain take 'em, ha' eat up all my Beans, I think.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But you have a new Landlord, Roger. Old Sir Jeffry is dead, and there's his Son.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Say you so, Master! Bless you, Sir, I did not know your Father, not I, tho' I have paid him many a fair Pound —Nor I dan't know you; but an you be my Landlord, I'm an honest Man; and tho' I say it, pay my Rent well as any Body.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I don't doubt it, Friend—I am sorry your Harvest has not prov'd so good as you expected.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I hope, Master, for Luck's sake now, you'll 'bate me something of my Rent.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I can't do that, Roger—For the Taxes take away all my Money—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, as you say, Master, these Taxes are sad things, that's the Truth on't —Od they find out strange ways; they had got a Trick here once to make one pay for one's Head—Mercy on us, I was afraid they wou'd make one pay for one's Tail too—My Neighbour What de call um —says it cost him the Lord knows what in Buryings and Christnings—Adod 'tis a sore Thing, a Man must pay for Lying with his own Wife.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, 'twas a Grievance indeed; but Taxes can't be help'd, so long as the Wars continue.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Wars! Why what need there be any Wars? Can't People live peaceably and quietly among themselves—If they will squable, and play the Rogue, let 'em go to Law,; can't they set the Lawyers to work; I warrant they'll quickly make them as quiet as Lambs.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; but we are at Wars with a Prince that cares for no Laws but his own, nay he breaks them too, when 'tis his Interest—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why then Mercy upon us, I say—Well an how! may one wish you much Joy? Ha, you got a Wife, Landlord? By the Mess you are a pretty Man—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I'm not so happy yet, Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Say you so? Good lack, I'm sorry for't—Why now here's Master Trusty has a good▪ sweatly look'd▪ Gentlewoman to his Daughter—What think you of her, Landlord?—Od, and all Parties were agreed, she'd make a rare Bedfellow, I'm persuaded.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I believe Sir John is of your mind; have you any Interest with her, Father?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Not I, in troth, Master Lovely—but the Gentlewoman is of a sweet temper.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Do you think you cou'd persuade her to run away with him?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd, Sir —for a pretty Woman i the best Luggage in the World—for when a Man in wry, he may rest upon it; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You are waggish, Roger.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Roger will joke; there's your Acquittance, if Sir John please to sign it—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis the same thing if you sign it, Mr. Trusty.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: I find my Daughter signs the Note. stands fair in your Opinion, Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir—I hope you ar'n't angry! I meant no harm—I spoke as I thought; an I had a hundred Daughters —my Landlord, and Mr. Lovely, should have them all, and they wou'd, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you truly.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh! a hundred wou'd be too many.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Prithee hast thou never a single one at present?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Not that I know of, in troth, Sir; but an you'll do me a small kindness, Sir, I may chance get you one about fourteen Years hence.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That will be something too long to stay.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But what can I serve thee in, Roger?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why, Mrs. Belinda has a kind of a Maid cll'd rin, I have had a hankering mind after her these two Yars, the sliving Baggage will not come to a Resolution yet.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: You must apply your self to my Daughter, Roger, she'll be the best Advocate; but I doubt she's to for you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Too fine! nay, nay, I'll never quarrel ith that; an she can win Gold, as the Saying is, let her wear it.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: But I doubt you are not fine enough for her.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Mehap so, as yu say; indeed I have you such ay Cloaths as these Gentlefolk have, because I can't afford it, do ye see? else I shou'd like 'em well enough—In troth, I believe I have some Seeds of a Gentleman in me; for methinks now I like broad Cloath better than my Leathern Breeches; and a Holland Shirt, far before a Hempen one——adod methinks, I, I, I, cou'd be well enough contented with a Bottle of Wine every day—I am minly inclin'd to strong Beer— and don't care a Farthing i I never were to drink any small.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh! extraordinary Symptoms of a Gentleman, I'll assure you—Well, we'll speak to Dolly for you.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we'll all speak for you; go, go into the Cellar then, and drink thy Belly full.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Be sure to drink Dolly's Health.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Thank you kindly, Sir—Ay, ay, Master, that I will I promise you, in a full Horn—So Landlord, good by to you with all my heart Exit.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Now, Sir John, I'll send my Daughter to keep you Company, till I look for some Leases your Father order'd me to get drawn, which if you think fit to sign—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: If the Tenants are able Men, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Trusty,
sp.p: Oh! very sufficient Men, Sir John.Ex. Trusty.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, thou hast secur'd the Money, Constant; and my Advice is to dispatch the Woman, as fast as you can, and find some pretence to defer these Leases for two or three days—Sir Jeffrey is whimsical, and if he shou'd alter his mind, and come down—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Here wou'd be no staying for me, if he shou'd; therefore I design to be as quick as possible—but here comes the Star that guides me to Happiness.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And my Pilot—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What Voyage are you for, pray?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The everlasting Voyage of Matrimony, Child— and your Eyes are two such dangerous Rocks, that nothing. ut your Tongue can steer me into Harbour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But any of my Sex can steer you out, you'll be for crossing from Port to Port, to make that everlasting Voyage agreeable.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, faith, where I drop my Anchor, there my Vesse is moor'd for Life—Well, Constant, what says the Lady? will she let thy Habeas Corpus remove her?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Out of one Prison into another, is it not so, Constant?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Interrogating! nay then 'tis proper to be alone; there is a very pretty Collection of Prints in the next Room, Madam, will you give me leave to explain them to you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Any thing that may divert your Love Subject. Ex.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Can Belinda term my Arms a Prison?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But Marriage is a Better, Constant.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I'll not make it one; I'm a true British Subject, I'm for Liberty and Property—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And Self-interest, for they are inseparal.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I hope our Interests are the same, and when lnk', will be the stronger. Cme, Madam, condr our opportutunity may be short, we ought to be quick, to prevent discovery; I have your Father's consent.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Discovery! Why what is a but reasonable I be let into the Secret, if I'm in danger of ating the Punishment, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why that Sir John, Belinda? I know you are inform'd of all, then do not ridicule my ardent Passion; 'twas my Love for you that first inspir'd me with this Stratagem; then prithee come, my dearest—— taking her hand.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Not a step, sweet Servant—I'll know terms I capitulate, e'er I surrender.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Terms! Madam! Has not Dolly told you of the Plot?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, upon your Father and mine. Captain, but I don't think it safe to join in it: Suppose my Father be blg to pay back this Money; may not that be provocation enough to disown me? and i your's shou'd for this trick disinherit you?—What Joynture can you make me?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My Heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pshaw! that is the slippery'st piece in all Fortune's Treasure—we never can be certain of that— —

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Then my Soul.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Where shall I find it? the Learned cn't agree where to place it; therefore I'll have no trouble abut th.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Then take my Body for Bail, that I'm sure is forth coming.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay, but there's No—No exeat Regnum in Love's Court—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: To cut off all Objections, I settle this Money upon you; and either put it out to Interest, or purchase some pretty Retirement; where, if Belinda loves but half so well, as I flatter'd my self she did, I can forsake all Courts and Company—and prefer a Grott with Her, before all the trappings of the Fools of Fortune—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Generously said! I have try'd thee, Constant; and find thy Nature like thy Name; there, take my Hand— my Heart was thine before.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: 'Tis sympathy of Souls that join us two,
Death only shall our Gordian Knot undo.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Until that Hour, Belinda will be true.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Joy to thee, my Friend; and you, Madam, we overheard your Protestations—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Prithee let's fetch the Parson this Minute—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To choose—Ladies, we'll return instantly. Ex.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Prosperity to Belinda!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dare not you bear me Company, Girl?
Have you the Heart to let me run this Hazard alone?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, what wou'd you have me do?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Even what I design to do—Marry—for I'm sure thou lov'st that hansome young Fellow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I find you understand your own Constitution, Belinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So well; that if you follow my Example, you'll act as resolutely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thine is a rash Venture, if Sir Jeffrey shou'd not forgive him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The more honourable; we have Love, and that's the best Estate in a married Life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: True, but what can we poor Women do, whose Parents are not inclin'd to gratifie our Wishes;—you know mine are set against this Match—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pugh, Parents will relent in time—If not, Mr. Lovely has Fortune enough to make you happy—You love him, and he loves you; were I in your place, I'd fain see a third shou'd part us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: True, I do love him—but will not marry him, without a Portion; he shall never throw that in my Dish, I resolve.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
An admirable Resolution truly—Then you'll go on; hang your Head, cross your Arms, sigh your Soul into the Air—sit up all Night like a Watch Candle, and distil
your Brains through your Eye-lids—for so I have done— no, no, Girl, e'en let us save our Trs tll arried.

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.p: What, you think like most Wives, we shall have occasion for them then, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: As it may fall out—Then let us marry whilt we are young, that we may be able to bear it with the better Courage—But here's my Father over head and ears in Papers; I tremble though, to think what he will say when he finds the Cheat.

div2.stage: Enter Trusty, with Papers in his hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And see who is behind him—— Enter Num and Slouch.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I have a sudden thought how to divert my Father's Anger; when all's discover'd, I'll put it in practice—— Sir, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Od, She speaks, Slouch——Nay, Madam, I'm your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Ha! what's that—Why, Sir, I admire—hey day, where are the Gentlemen, Daughter?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Sir, why here is one Gentleman; indeed I can't say much for Slouch—

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Why don't you answer me, ha?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I know not, Sir, they went out soon after we entred.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They whisper'd, Sir, and left the Room.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Ha! I don't like that—

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Mehap they are gone to fight for Mrs. Belinda. A she'd marry you, Master now, how rarely they'd be h ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Od, so they wou'd, as you say, Slouch——Madam, what say you? Mr. Trusty, shall we make an end on't? I know you are a merry Man, and did but joke wo' me.

sp.speaker: Trusty:
sp.p: Say you so! I doubt you won't find it so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: No! why I verify believe the Gentlewoman has kindness for me, by her Looks; how say you, Mistress? speak the Truth, and shame the Devil, as the saying is— han't you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, if I must speak the Truth, 'Squire, I have as much kindness for you, as for any body; my Father commanded me to love.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Ay! why what say you to Sir John Constant? don't you like him better?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I did once, Sir, but I don't remember I ever had your Consent in that.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: You have it now then—'tis time enough; it is good to know what one has to trust to.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Leave now, Sir, comes too late, he may have chang'd his Mind.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: No, no, you shall be married to Night, he shan't have time to think of Change.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, fair and softly—he shall not have her to Night, mehap—for all your haste; Slouch, stand by me.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: That I will, Master, in any Ground in England.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Humph! I guess her drift— Aside.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then 'tis time for me to think on't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Hey day, What's here now!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I don't like Marches huddled up in haste; and I learnt from your Instructions, Sir, to consult my future Happiness in a Marry'd State.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Good again, I'faith, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Your future Hapiness why what can cross your future Happiness, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: What, will they quarrel about me now, Slouch, ha?

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: The Woman has a woundy mind to you, I see that, Master.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sir John Carriage is more loose and familiar than formerly—from which I draw this Conclusion, Sir; that he thinks his Quality may now command, and when a Lover loses respect, his Sincerity quickly follows. I like not the method of our Quality—The Name of Husband without the Fonddness, is like a Title without an Estate, of no value with the Wise.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am of her Opinion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: And I too, faith—Od, she talks rarely; I shall have her, I find—In my Conscience I love her ten times the better, because I see she loves me—and let me tell you, Sir, your Daughter is honester than you are—Why shou'd you pretend to cross her Will? You plainly see, she has a mind to no body but me—Mun—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I plainly see you are a Fool, and she's another—

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Look ye, say what you will o' me, but don't affront her; for all you re her Father, I won't let my Wife be calld Names, de ye see.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Zounds, get out of my Doors.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Ay, but who is the Fool then?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pray be calm; since you once lik'd the 'Squire for a Son-in-law, I hope I shan't disoblige you in preferring him before Sir John for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Disoblige him! Who cares if it ds, Mdam, along—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha, ha. If thy Father shou'd take thee at thy Word, Belinda?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Stars forbid—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Did you ever see such a provoking Creature?
Oh, Sir John, 'Tis well you are come—Where have you been? You are in danger of losing your Mistress here.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, I have taken the best way to secure her.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If the Parson can do it, for we have got him in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: To Constant. Humour what I say—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Now Mistress, You had best bring your Objections again, and spoil your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: To Num. If you dare maintain your Chm to me. I am yours— I say again, Sir. I like the 'Squire best.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Dare! od I, I, I, I, dare a, a.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What dare you do, Sir?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: What a Plague do you stare at so?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What was that you mutter'd! what dare you do?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: I dare do as much as you dare do—What a Po. I'm not to be frighted wi' Looks, mun.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Od, take heed Master, he has a woundy long Sword.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: A Sword! I care not a—for his Sword, nor him neither. Walks about in a heat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Sir John, this Gentleman is a Person whom I esteem.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and one that She intends to marry too.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Marry! when, Sir?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: When she pleases, Sir; now, an you'll lend us your Parson?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis fit you ask him leave indeed!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I'll lend you my Sword in your Guts first.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Your Sword in my Guts—Slouch, give me your Cudgel. Snatches his Stick.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Ads blead, clear the way, clear the way; I'll turn the 'Squire loose to any Man in Zomersetshire.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Come, out with your Spit, mun—Wounds, an I don't make ye put it up again, I'll ne'er strike stroke more.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: The Devil, he'll knock me down. Lays his hand on his Sword.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Oh don't draw, Sir John—lay down your Stick, Sir, and get you about your business, or you'll oblige me to use you worse than I am willing to do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Excellent Sport, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Incomparable, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Who cou'd have thought the Lout so couragious— —Oh pray let us have no fighting.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: You have had your Answer, Sir, therefore pray be gone quietly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You 'fright me out of my Wits, 'Squire; pray go out of my Father's House peaceably; if you love me, do, we'll find some other way.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Love ye, yes, I do love you; or what makes me in such a Passion, think you? Well, well, I will go out— Look ye, Sir, an you be a Man, follow me; I'll box fairly with you now, for half a Crown, and this Gentleman shall hold Stakes, and see fair play—If you dare now?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Fie, fie, 'Squire, Gentlemen don't use to Box.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Box, ye Blockhead, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Blockhead!—Zounds, I'll learn you to call Names.

sp.speaker: Slou.
sp.p: Come on, Sirrah, I'll fight with you at the same time— begins to strip I'll stand by Master, for the honour of Zomersetshire.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Death, you shamble ham'd Dog! I'll beat your Head off— Gives him a box of the Ear.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Ay! are you there? faith, come on—come on.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hold, hold, two to one is odds. parts them.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Let me alone, Sir, egad I'll fight'em both.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what do you do, 'Squire, fight with a Footman! pray leave off, or you'll disoblige me for ever.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Oh Lord, oh Lord! what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: What care I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, don't you care for your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but I won't be made a Fool on; but I will go—an I were sure you wou'd not be forc'd to marry this same Spark—I won't leave you in the lurch, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
