sp.p: No, no, 'Squire, they shall not force me, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.p: Then I go—but look to't, an I catch you out of this House; by the Mass I'll rib you. Ex.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Adod, I was out of all Patience with the Fool— Come, take her by the hand, Sir John, you shall be married this Minute, we'll settle business afterward.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you'll repent this hasty Match.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What means Belinda?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You shall know within.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Get along —in my Soul, I think the whole Composition of Women is Contradiction. Ex. omnes.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: There, honest Coachman, drink my Health; but pray can't I speak with the Gentlewoman of the House?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Sir David has no Wife, Sir; but here is a young Lady, I'll call her Maid; Mrs. Lucy, Mrs. Lucy, here is a Gentleman wou'd speak with your Mistress—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: A Gentleman! bless me, how came you to let a Man in, Thomas, in Sir David's absence?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Sir David bad me himself, or you may be sure I had not done it— I thank you, Sir. Ex. Coachman.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What do I see? Mr. Faithful!

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: The same! How fares my Love, my dearest Laura? Quick, bring me to her, I am impatient till I see her.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, she wou'd be as impatient as you, if she
knew you were here —But by what Miracle did you prevail with Sir David?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Prithee ask no Questions—I'll inform thy Lady; haste, my time's but short, therefore must improve it.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, follow me then. Ex.

head.stage: SCENE draws, and discovers Mrs. Laura at her Spinet.

div2.stage: After the Song, Enter Lucy and Faithful.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What did that Blockhead bawl so for, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: To have an Acquaintance of yours admitted, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: An Acquaintance of mine!——ha! my dear Faithful! am I awake? and is it really he?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: My dearest Love— run into one another's Arms. Oh let me hold thee here for ever, for ever taste the Nectar on these Lips——There is still the same Fragrancy, as when we parted last.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh! it was a fatal parting—say my Love, how cam'st thou here? for the old Monster allows no Mortal to visit me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: By Stratagem, my Dear; he sent me hither in his Coach, yet knows not I am come; thou shal't have the Story at more convenient leisure; but now let us employ our time to advantage.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Heavens! how I tremble! he'll soon be back, for he's never out above half an Hour—Lucy, watch below. Ex. What can this short interview avail us? which way shall I get out of his power? The nauseous Goat told Lucy he design'd to marry me himself—and casts such loving Looks every time he sees me, that I am half distracted, lest he shou'd give his horrid Passion vent.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! Confound his Passion with himself—— consent to fly with me to a Friend's House in Town, where we'll be married, and put it out of his Power to confine thee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: With all my heart—My Prison is so odious to me, I need but small intreaties to make me quit it —this is the Closet he keeps my Writings in; if we cou'd contrive to get them along with us, or he'll give us trouble enough to get 'em out of his hands, here—don't you think one might wrinch it open?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: So he may prosecute us for a Robbery.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Let him, I'll meddle with

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! there's Sr David ent Passion, beating all the Servants in before him.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Undone! What shall I s;ay what will become of thee?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sink the Villain—he Deare▪ take no thought for me; seem not to know me; pretend surprize, and beg me to be gone; leave the rest to me.

div2.stage: Enter Sir David, beating his Men in upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sir. Dav.
sp.p: Ye Dogs, what have ye done, ha?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: What do you beat me for? Did you not bid me carry him home?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Zounds, not to my home, you Rascal. Beats him.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: What do you mean, Madam, by saying you don't know me; 'sdeath, did not I lodge here last Night?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: How's this? how's this?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, I never saw you before; neither do we let Lodgings, then pray be answer'd.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: A very pretty trick, saith▪ What, have you a m to cheat me of Hos, and my Prtmana—Look ye, Madam, this won't pass upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: No, nor upon me, neither, Sir.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, your humble Servant; I think I have had the Honour to see you somewhere. I am in dispute with this Gentlewomn here; she'd fain perswade me I have must my Inn, — —and that I did not lie here last Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Lye here! Why, do you take this Lady for an Hostess,

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, she is very handsome—but why the Devil must eauty make her deny her Calling—Ad, you Country Gentlemen, do so kiss and flatter your Landladies, that egad, they don know where their Tails hang—but we make them know thmselves in London—Once more, will you call your Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! ye Dogs, I'll be reveng'd on you.

div2.stage: beats his Servants, they run off.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The Fault's not mine, Sir; Tomas bad me let him in.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
What no Attendance yet? So, he, Tpster, Chamberlain — —Pray Sir sit down— I wrrnt Ill ke
Body hear—Heark ye, you Mistress—You are not above your Business too, are you?to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, I shall go distracted.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Pray Sir know your way out, don't think I'm one of your Wenches.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Good lack, ha, ha, what are you a fine Lady too? the Devil! Sure this is a Bawdy-house—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I dare swear you'd make it one if you cou'd—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, I take this for an extraordinary Inn—Pray do me the favour to sit—I'll beat the Chamber down, but I'll make some Body come up. So, ho, the House here—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: A plague split you, what do you make all this Noise for? oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Pray, Sir David, humour the Gentleman, for I fancy he is a little beside himself.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Humour the Devil! Hell and Furies! This must be some Rogue—Here, where are you Rascals?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ay Scoundrels, where are you? Ye Dogs, what is the reason we can have no Attendance? Strikes one of them. Fetch us a Bottle of Claret, Sirrah, and bring us word what we can have to Eat—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Bring a Bottle of Claret! bring a Halter— What do you strike my Servants for? ha, Sir.

sp.speaker: Faith,
sp.p: Your Servants, Sir! They are my Servants, as long as I pay for what I call for—Ho! I find you are the Landlord of this well-govern'd Inn—Make your People more tractable, de you hear, Sir? Or I shall not only beat them, but you too——Death ye Villains, why don't you stir?Strikes another.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What will be the end of this? All my Comfort lies in his Assurance—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Zounds, let him stir if he dares—Get out of my House, Sirrah, or I'll lay you by the Heels; don't put your Shams upon us—Don't Bully here; I thought you was wounded when I lent you my Coach—But I find you are a Rogue, and either design'd to Rob my House, or
Ravish this Lady—Fetch me a Constable the Devil! I'll Box with you, if you're for Boxing——Get into that Room Laura, I'll deal with him I warrant ye. Put Laura in.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh unfortunate! How shall I ever see him agen?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I'll be here about an Hour hence before this Door.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ay! But to what purpose?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I thought you was wounded when I lent you my Coach.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Wounded, Sir! why so I am, and my Wounds bleed afresh with Vexation— —Was it your Coach! I and I was mistaken then, you are not my Landlord; I ask your pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Rot your Pardon—How now, who the Devil are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am this Gentleman's Servant—Bless me, Sir, what do you do here? Why Sir John and Mr. Lovely has been searching all the Town for you; they brought a Surgeon to the Talbot, and not finding you there, nor no where else, sent me to ask this Gentleman's Coachman where he drove you to, and swear if you be not found presently, they'll Indict the Coachman for your Murther.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I wou'd you were all Hang'd for Company; why what a Plaguy Mistake was here?—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! a lucky Hint —Bless me, Sir, I am under the greatest Confusion imaginable, can you forgive me, Sir? Upon my Honour, I thought I had been in my Inn; I ask a thousand Pardons, pray excuse me to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Sir, never trouble your Head about the Lady.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Why Sir? I'm a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: A Gentleman Sir! And what then Sir?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: And am Master of an Estate to support that Character Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Zounds, was ever Man so plagu'd, to have his Servants kick'd about like Foot-balls, his House thunder'd about his Ears like a common Inn, then to be told impudently, I'm a Gentleman, and have an Estate to support that Character?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I ask your pardon agen Sir, for the unlucky Accident, in mistaking your House, but cannot apprehend what Crime I have committed in my Apology.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Sir, without any manner of Apology, I wou'd be very proud to wait on you down Stairs.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: By no means, Sir—I must not permit that.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Death and the Devil, be gon without it, then.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: That I will Sir; but intreat the favour of seeing the Lady first; upon Honour I was never so concern'd in my Life: I wou'd not for Five hundred Pound quit the House, till I have convinc'd her of my Error, and made my Acknowledgment upon my Knees.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Zounds, here's the Devil to do about her— Which way shall I get rid of him?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Pray Mrs. inform the Lady of my Resolution.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Hark yee Huswife, stir out of this place, and I'll break your Neck down Stairs.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Why then I must be guilty of a second Rudeness to acquit my self of the first, I think that's the Room the Lady went into, Sir. Going towards the Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, Sir; where the Devil are you going—Zounds, advance one Step farther, and I'll indict you for a Robbery.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, since you are so positive, Sir, I will be gon; but pray Sir, is that Lady your Grand-daughter, Daughter, Neice, Cousin, or, or—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: 'Tis my Wife, my Wife, my Wife, my Wife Sir, do you hear that and tremble.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ods my Life, Sir, I beg your pardon with all my Heart and Soul—Your most Obedient, humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: The Devil go with you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To Lucy. My Master has not a Souse of Money, else you wou'd not want your Fee. We were Robb'd coming down. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Zounds Sir, What do you loyter here for? Why don't you get after your Master. Go, troop. Turns him out.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you sauntring here, get in to your Mistress! What do's your Chops water at the sight of a Man, ha?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I'm sure you are the worst Sight I cou'd have seen at present. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I don't understand this Mistake tho'—He is a strapping young Dog; I wish Laura had not seen him—— But I'll go see if he is gone, lest there shou'd be more Regy at the ttom. Exit.

div2.stage: Enter on one side Faithful and Manage; on the other Constant and Clinch.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: FAithful, well met, I was going in search of thee; my Affairs are ended, what Hopes of thine? Did the Project turn to thy Advantage?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: It gave me entrance to the Charming Fair, who receiv'd me with equal Transport; but just as she consented to come away with me, the old Fox return'd —A Curse of his Diligence—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I came timely to my Master's Rescue, Sir; and when his Pockets are replenish'd, I hope he'll own it.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: That I will, Manage.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis now in my Power to lend thee Twenty Pieces, Friend —There they are— Gives Money.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I thankfully accept them; and next the finishing my own Wishes, I am pleas'd thou hast gain'd thine; but after what Method to pursue mine, Heaven knows: I told Lucy I wou'd be about the Door in an Hour, but I know not if 'twill be in Laura's power to get out, or what can disguise me, Sr David will certainly know me again, if he sees me—The me is well nigh expir'd,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I have a Thought!—Cou'd you procure my Master a Red, or Blue Coat, in this Town, think you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I have my Regimental Surtout I rid down in, you know.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Right, that will do; I told him I serv'd an Officer; I warrant we'll pass upon him—Come, strip Clinch, strips give me my Cloaths again— Strips and Champer with Clinch again. But 'tis necessary, Sir, that you change your .

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And what if you put a Patch cross your Cheek, like a Scar?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: With all my Heart—I must, and will redeem her, or cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, Twenty thousand Pound gives an edge to Invention.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: So now I am in Statu qu.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Were she not Mistress of a Groat, I shou'd prefer her before the most celebrated Beauty in the Kingdom; our infant Years first sowed the Seeds of Love, which as we grew, ripen'd to a perfect Passion; her Parents dying, left her to the Care of mine; oh in what Pleasure have we past the Day, and quarrell'd with the Night that call'd us from each other. Whilst I made the Campaign with you, Captain, my Father died! Oh fatal Thought, her Friends remov'd her to this Sir David Watchum's, 'tis twelve Months since, during which time, till now, I never cou'd find means to see or hear from her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I know the Story perfectly well, and wish thou may'st succeed with all my Soul; but I find he is upon his Guard—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: If he cou'd summon Hell to guard her, I will by Policy or Force release her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why then, pray resolve upon which immediately; shall we lay open Siege or Blockade his Cittadel. The Head must always work before the Hands—Now 'tis necessary, e're we attempt, to know the weakest and strongest Parrs; then we open our Trenches and Cannonade the Place, ruin their Ramparts, make a Breach, and then give the Assault, take the old Rogue by the Throat, plunder his Castle, and carry off the Booty— Which is the Lady, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Manage talks like a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ah, if we cou'd do that, Manage! I have good Interest in the Town—And they have notice of my Coming—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So much the better; the more Friends we have in the Garrison, the sooner we shall become Masters of it —Well, as I am chief Engineer, and half the Artillery, I must survey the Ground to find the most convenient Place to raise my Battery. But away, away, Sir, and disguise your self; the Drum beats— leave the rest to Fortune, she cannot always run against us— I have known the Sun rise upon a private Centinel, who before his Setting was a Captain of Foot—Nothing like Diligence and Courage to nick the fickle Jade.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come, thou shalt be dress'd in a Moment Ex. omn..

div2.stage: The Out-side of Sir David's House, Sir David in the Garden before his Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I remember Saving of a certain Philosopher, That nothing is harder to keep than a Secret; but I think 'tis ten times harder to keep a handsome Woman—I am strangely affected with this last Accident; and then the t'other Rogue that was here in the Morning, that serves an Officer—A pox on these Office for they have more Stratagems in their Heads, than all the Kingdom besides. But I have order'd the Smith to Barricade my Windows, from the Cellar to the Garret, he'll be here immediately, but Laura must not see him—Poor Girl, she's terribly frighted at my Dog of a Coachman's Mistake; I have invited her into the Garden, here she and her Maid comes.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What favourd Davil, , hs procur'd us this Liberty? It happens as I woud have it, if Faithful he but here now▪

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I'm amnd —For 'tis the fast fresh open Air you have breath'd these twelve Months, Madam. But suppose Mr. Faithful shou'd be here! Yonder's the old Argus, he resolves to watch you I see.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay then!

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well Madam, How do you after your Fright? I sent for you into the Garden, to take the Air—The Air is gd after a Fright —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Ay, if one cou'd change the Place too, Sir David, but the Air of my Chamber and this is much the same—But let where I will, if you are there, I find no Difference in the Air— I know not what ails me, but when I see you▪ I draw Breath.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ha! she loves me▪ Oh happy — —Ir, Madam! And are those Sighs pleasant or painful, pray?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh very painful, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Then you must have a Husband to care those Sighs. Child.

div2.stage: Faithful and Manage appear between the Scenes.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: She's here! Oh the charming Maid—but that old Monster is with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What think you of a married Life, Lra▪

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Of nothing better—I might dissemble like many of my Sex; exclaim against Marriage and Mankind; profess to dye in a Cloyster, or a Maid at large—Mask my real Inclinations, fain Indifference to Love, and place all my Happiness in my own Sex—But I have a Heart too sincere; and therefore frankly own, that the utmost of my Ambition is to be a Wife.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: To me she means—Oh how shall I deliver her!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well said, Madam; why shou'd a Lady lose the prime of her youth, when she may do so much good in her Generation; I resolve to follow your Example to a hair.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Good Wits jump—I resolve to marry too; I have every day fresh Offers, very advantagious Offers, but my Heart is prepossess'd, dear Laura, for I will own it now, I love you exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So, now 'tis out.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: More, if possible, than you love me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: That's very possible, truly.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Love her! Oh the rank old Goat; Death! that Confession has made me loose all Patience.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, pray be content a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Come, don't blush, Laura; thy Sighs betray'd thy Love, but I'm discreet.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Now do I long to tell him he lies in his Throat.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Egad, Sir, you had better lose your longing at this time.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What do you say, Sir—that I love you! your Opinion is small proof of your Discretion.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why so, Child?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Because you never was more mistaken in your Life; for instead of loving you, I hate you mortally.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Oh blessed Sound!

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Really! but why so, prithee?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay, you love without Reason; and perhaps I hate by the same Rule.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if her declaration be not so kind as you wou'd have it, it▪ is not the less sincere.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Is it not, Gilflirt, after what I have done for her?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Yes, you have done for me, I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, pray be not angry, but state the Case right.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: If Love has render'd me charming in your Eyes, consider how he has drawn you in mine.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: She's amiable, you ugly——She's gay, you morose— She's Generous—you a Miser—She's sixteen—You sixty—She has the finest Teeth in the World——You but one in your Head, and that shakes, and the first Fit of Coughing, good by to it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A Devilish Wench——She has drawn him to a Hair.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Mark Lucy's Description, and then tell me if these be not irresistible Charms, for one of my Age and Constitution.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What Woman do you think, Sir, on this side fourscore, wou'd have such a Bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: She shall, Mistress, or she shall have no body, mark that; and your Witticisms, Mrs. Frippery, shall get you nothing— How now! who do you want?Faithful and Manage come forward.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: My dear Faithful! I know him in all Disguises; how shall I forbear running into his Arms?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Have a care, Madam, if you discover you know him, you'll never see him more; Manage has some Plot in his Head, by his winking.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What is it you look at, Sir! why don't you speak?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Be calm, Sir, and take no notice of the Lady.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I was so charm'd with the fineness of the Prospect in that Moment you spoke, Sir, I was not master of my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: And now you are Master of it, Sir, what have you to say?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir; only having the misfortune to break my Chariot—I took a walk this way, till it is put in order again; and coming by this House, my Man told me that you entertain'd some hard thoughts of him, from some discourse that pass'd between you to day—So I presum'd to call, to clear his Reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: This is the Officer! A Rogue in red now; and the Simple-hunter with him—I don't like 'em—As for that, Sir, you need not give your self any farther trouble, for I have nothing to do with his Reputation, nor yours neither.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I hope 'tis no offence to look about me a little; this House is finely situated—'Tis the best Air I have breath'd this Twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Pox o' your Compliment—That's your Mistake, Sir; 'tis the worst Air in the Universe—Let me advise you to get out of it as fast as you can; for 'tis very fatal to Strangers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He tells you truth, Sir; for ever since I breath'd this Air, I have neither eat, drank, or slept with Ease.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
I am sorry for that, Madam; but I find a quite contrary
effect; methinks I feel new Life, and I have a strong hope to carry off the Health I wish.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I wish, Sir, your Legs wou'd be pleas'd to carry off your Body.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, I will not be troublesome—but I desire you wou'd give me leave to take a view of your Gardens; I have bought me a small Seat in a Country Village, and I design to have a pretty Garden made.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Ah! wou'd you were buried in the Garden—go, get in, Gentlewoman, go—he has no business with you, you don't belong to the Garden.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To Lucy. Find some way to bring your Lady down again; do you hear? and let her pretend— Whispers to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I hear; but how to put it in practice, I know not.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I am distracted! Oh Invention! where art thou? help me Brains, or cease to think.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What do you loiter for, ha? get in—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir David, you use us like Slaves; send us in and out at pleasure—Is my Lady a Person to be treated so by her Guardian? These twelve Months we have not seen the shadow of any Hat but yours—I'm sure nothing that's Male has reach'd our Eyes.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why how now, Mrs. Prate-apace; if you don't like your living, troop off. Go—There are more Servants to be had.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I shall certainly discover my self, if he goes on at this Rate—Sir, I had rather quit this place immediately, than you shou'd incommode the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Pray Sir David, mind your own Servants, you shall never have any power over mine. Sir, let me advise you to tarry till to morrow; 'tis dangerous travelling too late; let me intreat you stay in this Town till to morrow—What said Manage to you Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ay, pray take my Lady's advice, Sir. You shall know within; take Courage, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Zounds, get in, I believe you want to lie with him all Night, you are so concern'd for his stay.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I hope some brave Man will attempt the rescue of my Mistress. He pushes 'em in.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: My Heart swells at these Indignities, and I cou'd shake his detested rotten Soul, out of its wither'd sapless Carcass.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Be easie, Sir, Passion will do us no good—I have something in my Head may hit, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am sorry, Sir, I shou'd be the cause of your being angry with your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: My Daughter!

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I ask your Pardon, Sir, may be 'tis your Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: She shall be e'er long, Sir.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.l: You shall be Worms meat first. Aside.
I had better knock him down, and fetch her out this moment.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And the next moment fetches you to Goal. Indeed, Sir, you had better keep your temper:—You have made a very excellent Choice, Sir, wou'd all Hust mnage their Wies so, shou'd not have so many Cquers bread.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I don't design my Wife shall follow the way of the World.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Second him, Sir, keep him in talk a lttle—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: You do well, Sir, 'tis below a Man to let his Wife rule, and rattle where she pleases; to visit, and be visited by half the Fops; in the Nation; for my part, had I a Wife, I shou'd follow your Method.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: 'Egad, I believe I was mistaken in this Gentleman. I wish, Sir, I had this Lecture read to some that blame me for my Conduct.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: If you please, Sir, I'll go into your House, and write it down this moment; it shan't cost you a Farthing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I'll not give you the trouble, Sir, I shall remember .

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! undone, undone; help, help; oh Sir David! what have you brought upon us?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What the Devil do you bawl so for?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! the saddest Accident has befallen my poor Lady!—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! her Lady, said She?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Peace, Sir, and mind the Plot— Aside to Faithful.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What accident, ha? You roar as she had broke a Leg, or an Arm.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Worse, Sir, worse, much worse; She's mad, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Mad!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Ay, Distracted, Sir—When you thrust us in, she found the Smith barricading her Windows; assoon as ever she lid her Eyes upon the Irn ars; her looks grow wild, her
Starts and broken Speeches, convince me of her Brain being turn'd —When before I was aware—She catch'd up an Iron Bar, and broke the Blacksmith's Pate; She beat her head against the Wall—runs, skips, sings, dances, stamps, raves, and throws all the things about the Room—I wou'd have shut her in, but she set up such a Roar, that I left the Door open, and fled for my Life.—Make the best of your Plot, Manage— Aside.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Mercy on us! what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Here she comes, oh my poor Lady!—with your great Base Viol in her hand; oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! if she breaks my Base, I had rather lose five Pounds: Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have Patience, Sir, I may be serviceable to you in this Affair, as little Opinion as you had of my skill to day.

div2.stage: Enter Laura, with a Base and Papers; her Cloaths aukwardly hanging.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Give me Liberty and Love,
Give me Love and Liberty,
From an Iron Grate,
And the Man I hate,
Dear Fortune set me free.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: What design you by this, Manage?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To put you in possession of your Mistress, before I have done, Sir, if you'll be quiet.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What, are you a Blacksmith?To Sir David.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh pox o' the Blacksmith, how she harps upon him!—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Ho! now I know you, you are a Singing-master.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: A Singing-master! good lack, good lack—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Here is a piece of Musick, which I have just now receiv'd from London; 'tis part of the last new Opera—there, there, there's a Part for you. gives Sir David a Paper. Ha! are not you the new Eunuch? Ay, 'tis he! here, here, here's your part.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: A Letter, Oh! for an opportunity to read it. draws off by degrees.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Give me Liberty and Love.
Give me Love and Liberty— Come, why don't you sing.To Sir David.She beats time all this while, with her hand upon his head, and with her foot upon his toes.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Poor Laura, I can't sing, Child—Zounds, Death and the Devil, she has kill'd my Toe.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What, won't you sing, I'll break the Fiddle then.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Pray, Sir David, humour her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Let me advise you comply with her, Sir; she's possess'd, and with a very mischievous Daemon.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Come, begin. Give me Liberty and Love.

p.stage: They all sing whilst Faithful reads.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
Dear Faithful, find some way to deliver me, or what I now act in jest, will follow in earnest; I have all my Jewels and Writings about me; for I have broke the old Man's Closet for them, and I'll find a way to get money presently. Yours entirely,
Laura.
Yes, I will deliver thee, or dye for it. Manage, read that.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Recommend me for a white Witch to Sir David; let me alone for the rest.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Poor Lady! I am extremely concern'd for her, Sir; pray consult my Servant about her Distemper; in my Opinion she's bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I doubt so too, Sir; has he really skill in these matters?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: No Man in the Kingdom more, I assure you, he has cur'd several to my Knowledge, both in Spain and Flanders.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why do you look at me so? Did you never see an old Woman before? I'd have you to know, Mistress, I have been as handsome as you—but Age alters every body—I have been the Mother of sixteen Children—all Boys——Heark ye, let me council you—don't marry an old Fellow.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, why so pray?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Because your Youth will renew his Age—and you'll be plagu'd with him to eternity—I married an old fusty Guardian, because I cou'd not get out of his hands; which is the reason why you see so many Wrinkles in my Face, ha, ha, ha. In my conscience there he stands—What, can I go no where, but you must follow me—ye old cripling Cuckold you—Look ye how angry he is now at being call'd Cuckold——Yet he wou'd marry a young Wife— —ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Mercy upon us! how does such things come in her head?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: The Wildness of her Fancy—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I'll do your business for you, Sir; I have consulted the Stars, and find she is bewitch'd by an old Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: By an old Woman! Ay indeed she talks of an old Woman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It is a very troublesome Spirit that is in her, and must be charm'd out into another, or she can't be cur'd —Tell me, Sir, can you procure any body for that purpose?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Here's her Maid, won't she do?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What! Do you think I'd have the Devil put into me, Sir, I ask you pardon for that.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Heark! There's my Drum beating up for Volunteers— What say you my Lads, are you for the Wars? Her Majesty has honour'd me with a Collonel's Commission; I'm just now raising my Regiment—you shall all serve under me. Come—hold, now I think on't, I want a hundred Guineas to raise Men with—Heark ye, won't you lend me a hundred Guineas?To Sir David.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Lack a day, it makes me weep, to see how many sorts of Madnesses possess her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A good thought for some Money—Humour her, Sir, whatever she asks for, let her have.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Lend me a hundred Guineas, I say, or my Soldiers shall batter your House about your Ears.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: For Heavens sake, Sir, give 'em her, you'll have them again safe.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I wou'd advise you to let her have 'em, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, be sure you take care of them; there, there is threescore in that Purse, you may tell her there is a hundred; but take care I have them again. to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, when we have nothing else to do with 'em. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Give it me—so, now my Boys will you serve the Queen?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart, under you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: There then, there's Gold for you, Sirrah; gives him a Guinea. and what say you, you are a handsome proper Fellow, six foot high —I'll make you Serjeant of the Grenadiers—What say you, will you serve under me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Humph! He wou'd rather serve her another way, I dare swear. Aside.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
And know no Joy beyond it; serve ye!—by Heaven,
that I will, with my Life, through all Difficulties and Danger; and die by your side, or you off safe.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Then there's Money, my Hero, to forward our Design.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Laura, you must ¦ney; Luy take care . I hope, Sir, you'll

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I'll see to that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Return the Money, to whom? They are my Soldiers, the Money mine—I borrow'd it of the most confounded old Rogue in Peterborough; tell him I say so ——but you look an honest Man, I'll mak your : — you exercise, Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Lord, oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Serjeant take heed; to the right and left by half Flanks—form Files upon the Flanks of the Battalion—March—ha, ha, you are cursed dull, Serjeant —

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am a little aukward at first, Collonel, but I shall learn.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh!Stamps.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll teach you then— Silence, Join your right hand to your Firelock — Cock your Firelock— — Present; Fire—Excellent.
sp.l: Give me Liberty and Love,
Give me Love and Liberty. Sings.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh sad, oh sad! what shall I do? Pray Sir desire yr Man to try his skill,

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Manage, the Gentleman implores your Aid.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am ready, if he can find any body to make the Fment; it must be a Man, Sir—will you endure it your self?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: No, faith and troth not I!

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, Sir, to do you and the Lady service. I'll venture — —but take care, Manage, that you bring the Devil out of again — —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, that I can easily; for he is not half so hard to get out of a Man, as he is out of a Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Good lack! what shou'd the reason of tht be, I ¦der! Aside. Sir, I thank you heartily — a very thy Gentleman thi,— —Well, what , Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Stand still, I charge you—And do you fetch us an easie Chair, Mistress.— to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Ex.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Stay, I must limit your bounds; there Sir, you must not for your Life cross this Circle.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I shall observe you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very well; Pray, Madam, be pleas'd to fit down.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Sit down! why is Dinner coming?—Ho, cry a Mercy! you are a Barber; hold, hold, you shall shave my Corporal first, to try your Razor.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh Lord, oh Lord! what shall I say to her?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Keep your place, Sir——No, no, Sir, I am a Shoe-maker, and if I fit your Foot, and please you, I desire your Honour wou'd let me have the business of your Regiment.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then pray sit down, Sir, that I may take measure. She sits down. Now for you, Sir, you must kneel right before her— closer—closer yet; there, look full in her Eyes—Clasp both her Hands in yours. Manage pulls a Book out of his pocket, and looks on't.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Give me Liberty and Love,
Give me Love and Liberty. Sings

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: My Charming Angel, Oh let me kneel here for ever, for ever gaze on those dear Eyes; how I have languish'd for thee, Heaven only knows.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And what I have born for thee, Hell cannot match; Oh, if Manage fail in his Plot, I'm undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Fear not, my Love, he is lucky at Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: What are they doing?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Alpha, Beta, Gama, Delta.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Bless me, what are those the Names of the Spirits?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Philo se en pasias, glossais, kai en to panti poto, kai en to panti topo—Now do you be well, Madam; and do you seem to be Mad, Sir, quick, quick—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Why what a many Devils there are! certainly she has a Legion in her.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Where am I, Lucy? Methinks I wake from some untoward Dream.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: She recovers, Sir. How do you,

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: I'm glad on't. How dost thou do,

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Pretty well.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Death, Sir, keep your Place, or you'll poil

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha! my Brain-pan splits—I'm all fam, my boils o'er, give me room, I'll scale the Region of the , and the Winds down headlong on us all.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, he's stark Mad; What shall we do him now?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We shall do well enough with him; but keep your Pl for he's very Desperate.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Defend me Heaven, what ails the Gentlem▪

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: He'll kill us all; the Man's bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Here, here, Ladies stand in this Circle, and don't cross it for your Lives. Sets 'em in a Circle.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh pray Sir, read again—

sp.speaker: Faith,
sp.p: What's here, old Belzebub! No, 'tis his Sh Cracker; I'll set fire to it and blow it up—Ho, lo, where you Scoundrels, Dogs, Rogues, Cooks, the Devil wants his Dinner, and you must spit this Swine, Hell dines on Hog's Flesh to Day. Draws his Sword.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Undone, undone; the Spirit grows too strong for y Art! fly, fly, Sir, for Life—

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, save me, save me. Runs in and slaps the Door.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Now, now, make your Escape; he has slap'd the Door after him—Quick▪ quick—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: My Life, my Soul!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: My Angel, my All. End race.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! Don't stand Lifeing and Dearing now, but make haste to Mr. Trusty's, I'll bring the Parson after you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ay, good Madam, be quick.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Any where, good Manage.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Fly Manage, and bring Lovely with thee too, to be Witness of my good Fortune, this Hour makes thee mine for ever:
sp.l: Now in thy Arms immortal Joys I'll taste,
And quite forget our anxious Sorrows past.

p.hi: Now Heav'n be prais'd, we've Liberty at last.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p:
Oh, I'm Robb'd, Ravish'd, Dead and Buried—My Closet is broke open, and all my Writings gone; Mr. Conjurer,
Mr. Conjurer, can you help me to the Thief? Ha! no Body to be seen! Bless me—Lucy—Laura, why Laura? Ah Murder, Murder, Thieves, Thieves. Crys out till he comes down.

Here, where are all my Servants? Enter Servants. Run some one way, some another; make enquiry thro' the whole Town for Mrs. Laura; she is carry'd away by two Rogues or Devils, I know not which, run, run—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why if the Devil has carry'd her away, Sir, where can we run?

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: To Hell, ye Dog, do you stand to prate?—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Marry look her there your self an you will— Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Dav.
sp.p: Oh that I shou'd believe these Conjuring, Soldiering Rascals; but I'll find 'em, if they are above ground; and if they are mortal, I'll hang 'em, that's my Comfort. Exit.

div2.stage: The Street before Mr, Trusty's Door; Roger comes out of the House with a Pitch-fork on his Shoulder, and a Lantern in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
IT will be very dark e'er I get home—Od, I'm main Merry, Master Trusty keeps rare Nappy Ale, and Dick the Butler is an honest Fellow; Lord, Sirs, how bravely these Gentlefolk live—Methinks I like it hugely; and I'm persuaded, I was design'd for a Gentleman, but was spoil'd in the making; nay, nay, I was made well enough too, that's the Truth on't; but 'tis that Damn'd Jade Fortune that has spoil'd me; for an I had an Estate now, I know how to live like a Gentleman—I cou'd scorn the Poor, and screw up my Tenants, and wou'd sooner give Ten Pound to a Wench, than Two Pence for Charity; I cou'd quickly turn—My Cart into a Coach, and my Man Plod into a Coachman—I cou'd hurry into the Tradesmen's Books— Wear fine Cloaths, and never pay for them —Lie with their Wives, and make my Footmen beat their Husbands, when they come to ask me for Money. Get drunk with Lords, and break the
Watchmen's Heads—Scour the Streets, and sleep in a Bawdy-house—Sell my Lands, and pay no Debts—Get a Charge of Bastards for the Parish to maintain—Then, by the help of a Commission, Transport my self out of their Reach—

div2.stage: Enter Sir Jeffry Constant, in Riding Habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Do you hear, Friend?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Mehap I do—And mehap I do not; What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Nay, the Matter's not great—Do you live at that House?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I did a little while ago——When I was in the Cellar.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: A Comical Fellow. Then you don't serve Mr. Trusty?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No, Sir, I serve his Master, tho' as most Farmers do their Landlords.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I understand you: You Rent one of the Knight's Farms?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ay, and a Plaguy Dear one too——

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Say you so! That's pity; I'll speak a good Word for thee——Is Mr. Trusty at home?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I thank you heartily. Yes, Sir, he's at home. Runs to the Door and knocks. Trusty opens the Door and shrieks out, and throws it to again. Wookers, what's the Matter now?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Was not that Mr. Trusty?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I think so.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Within. Oh undone, undone; Clinch peeps out as affrighted. here's my old Master.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, I heard a Noise, but can't tell what they said—— But on you please to come wo' me, Sir, I'll carry you in the Back-way.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: The Back-way——What can be the meaning of this? Why shou'd he start at sight of me? There must be something more in it than I can fathom; and yet I think he's an honest Man. I never found any thing to the contrary. Prithee, Friend, knock again. Roger knocks, then listens.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: They are all asleep, Sir—For I cannot so much as hear a Mouse stir——

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Asleep! That's impossible——But come, Friend, shew me the Back-door you spoke of——

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Ay, Sir: But upon second Thoughts,——I must be a little wary too. Are not you some Rogue, that comes to rob the House
with half a dozen Pistols about you? For look yee, I'm an honest Man, and won't be drawn in for a Halter.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: You Rascal, Do I look like a Thief?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, nay, as for Looks—That's no matter, de yee see —I have known many a Rogue with as good a Countenance— No Disparagement to your's, I promise you. So that I shall not stir one step without you'll stand search—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I shall break your Head, Sirrah, if you provoke me, I tell you but that.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And what must I be doing on the mean time,—Ha! old Gentleman?—Break my Head, quotha!—You are mistaken— —We don't use to take broken heads in our Country, mun—Ha, ha, I won't shew you the Back-door now, and how will you help your self?—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I know all the Doors of this House as well as you— And can shew my self in— Going.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Can you so—But I'll watch you—I wonder who this old Fellow is.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Sure some Madness has seiz'd the Family; for certainly I'm not chang'd—Without Dispute, Trusty knows me; but I'll find the Cause presently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And so will I— Exit.

div2.stage: Enter out of the House Captain Constant, Lovely and Clinch.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: So, Sir, here's Musick to your Wedding, with a Witness. What do you intend to do now?—Do you think it possible to persuade your Father too, that he died of an Apoplexy?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I fear, Clinch, that's beyond the Art of thy Impudence to do—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, this Plot was none of my Impudence's contriving, that's my Comfort—I'm but a Servant; my Master told me, he was in Mourning for his Father—And faith I resolve not to believe the Father to the contrary. Such an entire Deference have I for all your Commands, Sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why thou can'st not sure have the Confidence to stand it out to his Face.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Never fear me, Sir—You don't know what I can do —What say you, Sir? Shall we persuade the old Gentleman into a Ghost; or will you own your Fault, and refund the Money?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Neither, Clinch—I have more Duty, than to attempt the ; and more Necessity, than to submit to the other—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, if you be so divided—What do you propose?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I know not what to do—I'm glad the Ceremony was over, before he came.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And the Money sent away—What think you of my House, till the Heat of the Discovery be over? 'Tis my Opinion your Presence won't be proper—I warrant Sir David will be in pursuit of Mrs. Laura presently too—But we have seen her fairly Marry'd; so that Faithful is out of Danger; we'll leave him here —

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Shall I not take Belinda with us? I fear as much for her, as for my self—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: So there's no Body fears for me, I find— Aside.
I am like to have my Part truly.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, trust to her Management—She turn'd the Act upon her Father, you know, and made him impose her own Choice upon her. Let Clinch stay and use his own Discretion—If he can banter Sir Jeffry, and save his Bones, let him: But be sure to give us notice of all that passes.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What if my Bones are broke?—I thank you heartily for your Love, Sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No, no, Clinch; take heed you keep out of the reach of his Cane.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Or he'll make me feel; he's Flesh and Blood—Heark, I hear him coming, Good bye to you, Sir— Runs in.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis time for us to fly— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Well, I'm glad my Lady's Marry'd; for if this old Spark had come three Hours sooner, I wou'd not have ventur'd Two to Ten of the Match—I can't imagine where the Bridegroom's gone—Nor what he will do, when my Master comes to have a right Understanding; but I resolve to keep him ignorant as long as I can. Ho, here he comes.

Oh, Sir, I am frighted out of my Wits; I went to serve my Lady's Italian Greyhound, and I found a great swinging Dog, as large as an Ox, with two great Eyes, as big as Bushels; and before I cou'd call out,—Whip it was vanish'd—

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Mercy upon us —'Twas certainly Sir Jeffry,— Clinch.Enter Clinch.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Sir, did you call—

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Did not you say your old Master appear'd in the Shape of a Dog?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, several times.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: In a huge great Dog?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: As big as an Ox.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, as big as an Elephant.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Ah! then it was certainly him I saw. Oh dear, oh dear, if the House be haunted, I must leave it. I cannot live in't, if I might have a Thousand Pounds; and may be, he'll appear to no Body but me—I am sure I never did him any harm; 'tis true, I did not love him, because he was something Stingey—— He never gave me a Farthing in his Life—

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Nay, for that matter, I have got many a fair Pound by him, and yet he appear'd to me to Day.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir. In what Shape, pray?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Like an Ox, or an Elephant.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: No, in his own Shape; but I wish I may never see him more, for I was horribly fear'd.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What had he a Cloven Foot, Sir, did you mind?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Nay, for my part,— I know not whether he had any Feet or no,—Ha! bless me, defend me,—Protect me— Avoid, Satan— Retreating all this while. I never wrong'd that Form, which thou hast ta'en; so tell him—And for my Money, I have accounted for that; and all Things are rectify'd— Exit.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Oh! shield me ye Stars. runs in.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: O Legs! save me, save me. runs in.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What? Am I become a Monster! Do I affright all I come near? What can be the Reason of this? The Doors are all Barricaded; and when I knock, none will answer—Prithee, Friend, ask some Body the Cause of these Disorders?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No! Sir, I'll not budge a Foot; for I dan't know what to say to you. The Family were all well, and in their right Senses, when I left them; and now upon Sight of you, they are all distracted, I think—I wish you be'n't a Conjurer, or heark ye, Sir,—Is not your Name Emmes—Rais'd by the French Prophets to Life again?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Sirrah, I believe you are the Devil: This Fellow will make me Mad. This must be some Stratagem to abuse me; and this Rogue is in their Interest. Why don't you go about your Business, Sirrah? What do you hanker after me for?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Nay—an you go to that, what do you lounge about
this House for?—Oh! Dolly, are you there; here's an old Gentleman is quite out of Patience.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Trembling above. Oh, oh, oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Hey day! What have you got the Palsy?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What ails you to tremble so, Sweetheart? Is Mr. Trusty within?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: I, I, I, I, I, o, o, o, o, Roger—Ha, ha, have a care, ca, care—Don't yo, yo, you come near him—Nor let him to, to, to, touch you, even with his Little Finger—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Bless me! What ails the Wench?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No, why what's the Matter? He has not the Plague about him, has he? Or is he a Spy from the King of France—Od an he be, I'll maul him—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Oh, oh,——'tis a, a, Ghost.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: The Devil it is— Takes his Pitchfork off his Shoulder, and holds it out at Sir Jeffry.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: A Ghost, where?—Who—What's a Ghost? Death, what means she?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Od's flesh, my Hair stands an end. Look ye—Keep off Mr. Belzebub, or—or—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Look ye, Sweetheart, what Frenzy has possess'd you, I know not—But if you take me for a Ghost—You are deceiv'd. Therefore look well at me —Do I not appear like Flesh and Blood?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Ay, bo, bo, bo, but we, we, we know yo, yo, you a, a, a, a, are not so, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Zounds, will they persuade me out of my Life? See, Friend,—Do I walk like a Spirit? Do's the Dead move, and talk as I do?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: When I am Dead,—If you ask me, I'll resolve you, if I can.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Why? Feel me, feel me—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Feel the Devil—Mercy upon me—Keep off, I say— Will ye—Or I'll stick your Ghostship thro' the Guts——

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What shall I do—Nay, prithee, Friend.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Friend me no Friends—Look ye, I am not to be coax'd by the Devil, when I know 'tis the Devil. Indeed when you are got into a Lawyer, or a handsome Woman, one may be trapan'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Why will you be so positive? Has any Body impos'd upon you?—Pray who told you I was dead?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Those that knew very well, Sir
But I am not able to bear the fight of you any longer—Now let Clinch take his Part.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Go to be Hang'd—Hell and Furies!—Ha, what do I see—My Son's Man! Sirrah, Sirrah, what makes you here?—

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Mercy upon me—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What do you stare at, Rascal, ha?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: But that I believe you are dead, Sir, or I shou'd swear you are alive—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: You believe I am dead, Rogue,—How dare you believe such an impud Lye?—Where's the Rake your Master? I find now who has rais'd this Report. Sirrah, what's your Business here?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: To wait on my Master, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: To wait on your Master——And where is your Master, pray?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, for my part, Sir, I am not qualify'd to answer a Spirit—There's Mr. Anthem, the Afternoon Lecturer, within. He has just Marry'd Mr. Faithful to a great Heiress which he brought in just now—Roger here may step and call him out a little.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: With all my Heart—If there be any thing that troubles his Mind, I'll go this Minute—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Sirrah—I'll qualify you for an Hospital—I will ye Dog— Runs after him.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Well run, Clinch; Well run, Ghost!—Ad 'tis a Plaguy Malitious Spirit tho'.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh. Runs in.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I'll venture to speak to it once more—— In the Name of Goodness—What is it that disturbs your Rest? Pray tell me; and as I'm an honest Man, I'll do you Justice as far as Twenty Pounds a Year Free-Land, and all the Crops of my Fa goes—For I perceive you was my Landlord, whilst you was Living; and tho' your Son seems to be a very honest Gentleman, yet I don't know what he may prove for a Landlord—Then pray speak, can I serve you?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to be angry—I must seem to comply with this Fellow—Yes, Friend, it is in thy power to serve me; if thou can'st procure me the sight of Mr. Trusty, 'tis with him my

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I'll do my best Endeavours, Sir—but keep your distance— He goes a little way, then turns back. But heark ye, Sir, suppose he won't come out, can't I tell him your Mind?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: No, no; I must speak with him my self—Death!—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Good lack—what, perhaps—your Soul won't rest else—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Heaven give me Patience!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Going, turns back. But after you have spoken with him, will you be quiet, and haunt this House no more? That's the Question, look ye!

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: A Pox of thy impertinent Interrogations; no—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: That's enough!—but hold, must he come out, or speak to you through the Window?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Any way, so I do but speak to him—Oh, oh!—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Very well, very well. Going. But heark ye, Sir Ghost —you'll be here—or Mr. Trusty will be woundy angry with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Oh Patience, Patience! or I shall burst. Aside. Ay, ay, I'll not stir.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Well, I'll take your word. Going. Hold, hold, one thing more, and I ha' done—Pray tell me the Nature of a Ghost— do you troubled Spirits fly in the Air, or swim in the Water, pray?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Oh! the Devil—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Mercy upon us! what, are you with the Devil, say you; Oh Heaven help you! Well then, are you sure he will see you? for every body can't see a Ghost, they say, especially if the Devil be in't.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Zounds, I tell you, he'll see me as plain as you see me.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, nay, that's plain enough—Well, I'll knock, but, but, but don't you come an Inch nearer me, I charge you Knocks.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Wou'd I had been a hundred Miles off, when I first saw thee. What has my graceless Son been doing!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Who's there?Speaks within.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Dolly, prithee tell Master Trusty that he must speak to this Ghost, or there's nothing to be done—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: I doubt he will not be persuaded to it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why, let him speak to it through the Window, or from the top of the House—so he does but speak to it; but in short, it must be spoke to, and by him, for it is a confounded sullen Spirit, and will tell its mind to no body else—He smells cursedly of Brimstone—Look ye, if Master will come out, it shan't hurt him— for I'll keep it off with my Fork, so tell him, Dolly.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: I'll inform him.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: So, I have done it you see—Here's Master Trusty.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I thank you. Going towards the Window.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: I am not able to stand, if it comes near me—Why are you thus disturb'd, Sir Jeffrey?—I assure you, your Son has done every thing very justly.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Why are you thus impos'd upon, Mr. Trusty, to believe I am dead?—My Son, quotha!—Oh that I had never got that Son— Weeps.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: I know not what to think; sure 'tis no Ghost.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Well, this thing is the likest Flesh and Blood, that ever I saw—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Pray do but touch me, Mr. Trusty,—'tis very odd, you will not be persuaded to touch me. Puts out his hand towards the Window.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Take heed, Mr. Trusty.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Why shou'd I fear, I never wrong'd him—I'll venture; but first— Holds up his hand as if he prayed now—ha! 'tis a real Hand,—He's living;—Sir, I am convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Say you so—why then if you are alive, the Fright's over, and I'm glad on't with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: I ask your pardon, Sir; I have been abus'd—grosly abus'd; Sir Jeffrey your Son came down in Mourning, and assur'd me you was dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: I'll make him mourn for something, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Ah! that he does already, Sir, for I have paid him all the Rents in my hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Have you so?—'Tis the last Rents he shall ever take for any Land of mine—I'll disinherit him this Day.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Oh! undone, undone for ever—Oh, oh, oh!Weeps.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Here's small Mirth towards, as far as I can find. I'll e'en take t'other Horn of Ale, and t'other Buss of Dolly— Ex. into the House.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What has that Rogue's Extravagance cost me? But if he starves for the future, I care not; he never shall get a Groat from me.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Nay, then we may all go for Soldiers. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh! I know not; but wherever he is —I am wretched, he has made me miserable, I'm sure. Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: No, Mr. Trusty; though you have us'd me dirtily, in making me the Jest of your Family; for you might have discover'd the Imposture with less precaution; yet I'll not take that advantage which the Laws allow. You have serv'd me long, and I believe you honest. I'll discharge you from what you have paid my undutiful Child—Let him take what he has got, and make the best on't.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: That's something however. Aside.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: You are generous, Sir Jeffry, even beyond my hopes: But Oh! there is yet a greater offence behind, which cuts me deeper than the Money—Alas! my Daughter—

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Is married to your Son; Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Then he is compleatly wretched—A Wife, and no Estate; ha, ha, ha; I'm glad on't with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: There's a kind Father now —I must give my Master notice of his good Fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Oh! say not so, Sir; be not glad of my Child's Ruin; had I known you liv'd, the Match had never been.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.p: Go; You are not the Man I took you for—you are but a Knave. You ought to have been as just to my Heir, as to my self—What, was your Blood fit to be popt into my Estate? Ha! or have you been really a Steward, and cheated me out of a Fortune for your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Sir, what I am Master off, I got fairly under you, part, and part under my Lord Belville in Ireland, whom I serv'd twenty Years in the same Post I do you; when he died, he trusted me with a Secret, which yet I have divulged to no Man; and when I do, the World will say I am an honest Man. Love first join'd their Hearts, and my Ignorance their Hands; use me as you please, but pardon them.

lg.head: A SONG, by the Author, and sung by Mr. Dogget.

lg.l: Wou'd you chse a Wife fr a happy Life,
Leave the Court, and the Cuntry take,
Where Dolly and She, young Molly and Prue,
Follow Roger and John, a ilst Harvest goes on,
And merrily, merrily Rake.
Leave the London Dames, be it spoke to their Shames,
To lig in their Beds till Noon;
Then get up and firetch, then paint too and patch,
Some Widgeon to catch, then look on their Watch,
And wonder they rise up so soon.
Then Coffee and Tea, both Green and Bohea,
Is serv'd to their Tables in Plate;
Where their Tattles do run, as swift as the Sun,
Of what they have wone, and who is undone,
By their gaming, and sitting up late.
The Lass give me here, tho' brown as my Beer,
That knows how to govern her House;
That can milk her Cow, or Farrow her Sow;
Make Butter, or Cheese, or gather green Pease,
And values fine Cloaths not a Louse.
This, this is the Girl, worth Rubies and Pearl;
This the Wife that will make a Man rich:
We Gentlemen need, no Quality Breed,
To squander away, what Taxes would pay,
In troth we care for none such.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Now I am happy—
Belinda mine, and you my faults forgive;
'Tis from this moment I begin to live.
Love sprung the Mine, and made the Breach in Duty,
No Cannon Ball can execute like Beauty.
But I'll no more in search of Pleasures rove,
Since ev'ry Blessing is cōmpriz'd in Love. Exeunt.
